{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Prose|date=September 2009}} The '''political crisis in Ukraine''' lasted from April to June 2007 was part of political stand off between coalition and opposition factions of [[Verkhovna Rada]] that led to the unscheduled [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007]]. It started on 2 April 2007 as a culmination of long lasting crisis and degradation of the parliamentary coalition when the [[President of Ukraine]] ([[Viktor Yushchenko]]) attempted to dissolve the parliament. The following day, in light of impending political unrest, the [[United Nations]] [[Resident Coordinator]], [[Francis Martin O'Donnell]] following an earlier call to deepen democracy and liberalize the economy,<ref>[http://www.un.org.ua/en/information-centre/news/352-2007-03-21]</ref> exceptionally issued an advisory statement of principles on behalf of the Country Team<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110727191528/http://www.un.org.ua/files/unct_ukraine_statement_en.pdf]</ref> (followed by a visit by former Estonian President [[Arnold Rüütel]] on 23 April).<ref>[http://www.un.org.ua/en/information-centre/news/364-2007-04-24]</ref>
The president signed a presidential decree based on several articles of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] ordering early parliamentary elections in [[Ukraine]] to be held on 27 May 2007,<ref name="order_264/2007">{{cite web|url=http://www.minjust.gov.ua/files/THE_DECREE_OF_THE_PRESIDENT_OF_UKRAINE.rtf|title=The Decree of the President of Ukraine On the Pre-Term Abatement of Authorities of Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine|date=2 April 2007|accessdate=11 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927225937/http://www.minjust.gov.ua/files/THE_DECREE_OF_THE_PRESIDENT_OF_UKRAINE.rtf|archive-date=27 September 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> though they were later postponed to 24 June 2007.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6594037.stm | work=BBC News | title=Ukrainian president delays poll | date=26 April 2007 | accessdate=22 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420233944/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6594037.stm| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He also ordered the government of Ukraine to finance the appointed elections. [[Verkhovna Rada|The Parliament]] and the [[Alliance of National Unity|government of Yanukovych]] called this decree unconstitutional and prevented fund allocation for elections. An appeal against the President's decree was lodged in Ukraine's Constitutional Court, which was considering the appeal.<ref name="appeal_CCU/2007">{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20070402/62965464.html|title=Yushchenko interference unconstitutional - Ukraine parl. speaker|publisher=[[RIAN]]|date=2 April 2007| accessdate= 4 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The Constitutional Court was expected to conclude its public hearing on Wednesday, 25 April 2007, following the presentation of the Government and Parliament's submission. The Court would then retire to consider their ruling.<ref name="CCU_25/04/2007">{{cite news|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=11457245&PageNum=0|title=Ukraine’s CC to complete questioning on early elections in 2 days|publisher=[[ITAR-TASS]]|date=21 April 2007| accessdate= 21 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
Viktor Yushchenko suspended the decree and postponed date of the election in order to have approved legislation on elections, the opposition, and the operation of Parliament.<ref name="postponed_conditional">{{cite news|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=11444273|title=Yushchenko doesn't rule out postponement of elections|date=18 April 2007|publisher=[[Information Telegraph Agency of Russia|ITAR TASS]]| accessdate= 21 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
==Dismissal of parliament and new elections== {{Politics of Ukraine}} {{main article|Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007}} Leading up to the dissolution of parliament was the eight-month power struggle between the president and the parliament.<ref name="president">{{cite web|url=http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/data/1_14702.html|title=President dissolves parliament|publisher=Press office of President Victor Yushchenko|date=2 April 2007|accessdate=3 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070901163210/http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/data/1_14702.html|archive-date=1 September 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Ongoing power struggles between the [[Alliance of National Unity|Coalition of National Unity]] and the opposition supported by the president [[Viktor Yushchenko]] frequently resulted in the opposition boycotting the parliament's plenary sessions.
Prior to the President's 2 April decree dismissing Ukraine's Parliament, 11 members of the opposition supported the governing Coalition of National Unity (formerly the ''Anti-Crisis Coalition''). The President of Ukraine, Viktor Yushchenko, claimed that the right of individual members of a parliamentary faction to support the governing coalition was contrary to the provisions of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 83|Ukraine's Constitution]].
Article 83 clause six, in what is commonly referred to as the [[Imperative mandate (provision in the Constitution of Ukraine)|Imperative mandate]] stated ''"According to election results and on the basis of a common ground achieved between various political positions, a coalition of parliamentary factions shall be formed in the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine to include a majority of People’s Deputies of Ukraine within the constitutional composition of the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine"''.<ref name="Yushchenko_FT_letter">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/11cb086c-e249-11db-af9e-000b5df10621.html |title=Ukraine's crisis needs a firm response |publisher=Financial Times |first=Viktor |last=Yushchenko |authorlink=Viktor Yushchenko |date=4 April 2007 |accessdate=4 April 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070506105213/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/11cb086c-e249-11db-af9e-000b5df10621.html |archivedate=6 May 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
The "Imperative mandate" provision of Ukraine's Constitution came under strong criticism by the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] as being undemocratic.<ref name="PACE_report">{{cite web|url=http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=/Documents/WorkingDocs/Doc07/EDOC11255.htm |title=Functioning of democratic institutions in Ukraine |date=17 April 2007 |accessdate=21 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705000656/http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=%2FDocuments%2FWorkingDocs%2FDoc07%2FEDOC11255.htm |archivedate=5 July 2007 |df= }}</ref> The Parliamentary Assembly in its Explanatory memorandum dated 17 April 2007 had emphasized{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
{{quote|Although Ukraine understandably has its own historic reasons to avoid the accumulation of power into the hands of one political force, it should nevertheless consider in the course of future constitutional amendments whether it would not be better for the country to switch to a full parliamentary system with proper checks and balances and guarantees of parliamentary opposition and competition. | Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe | 2007}}
The week before the president's initial decree, on 2 April, dismissing Ukraine's Parliament, thousands of supporters of the opposition gathered in Kiev, calling on the President dissolve the parliament. A similar number of supporters of Verkhovna Rada Governing majority also gathered in Kiev supporting Ukraine's parliament.<ref name="protests">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6512941.stm |title=Ukrainian rivals rally in capital |date=1 April 2007 |publisher=[[bbc.co.uk]] |accessdate=3 April 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416123619/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6512941.stm |archivedate=16 April 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 2 April, the President, Viktor Yushchenko, following a meeting with Prime Minister [[Viktor Yanukovych]] and Speaker of the Parliament [[Oleksandr Moroz]], signed the first decree dismissing Ukraine's Parliament sparking another political and constitutional crisis in Ukraine.
At 11 PM the President, in a televised speech to the nation, announced his decree dismissing the parliament and ordering early parliamentary elections to be initially held on 27 May.<ref name="president" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E3dwglMctT0|title=Yushchenko announces his dismissal of the Verkhovna Rada|publisher=[[YouTube]]|work=[[5 Kanal (Ukraine)|5 Kanal]]|date=2 April 2007|language=Ukrainian| accessdate= 26 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The Rada, passed a motion declaring the decree unconstitutional, in defiance of the president's decree continued to function,<ref name="837-16">{{cite web|url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=837-16|title=On prevention of actions that threaten constitutional law and order, civilian calmness and stability in Ukraine|work=Order of Verkhovna Rada|date=2 April 2007|language=Ukrainian| accessdate= 5 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> issued orders preventing funds allocation for elections,<ref name="839-16">{{cite web|url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=839-16|title=About political situation in Ukraine, related to order or President from 2 April 2007|work=Order of Verkhovna Rada|date=2 April 2007|language=Ukrainian| accessdate= 5 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> and canceled the order assigning [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine|election commission]] members.<ref name="844-16">{{cite web|url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=844-16|title=Cancel order of Verkhovna Rada about assignment of Central Election Commission members|work=Order of Verkhovna Rada |date=2 April 2007|language=Ukrainian| accessdate= 5 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The cabinet, supporting the parliament, refused to allocate funds for the new election.<ref name="595-2007">{{cite web|url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=595-2007-%EF|title=About immediate actions on implementation of Verkhovna Rada order N 837-V|work=Order of Cabinet of Ministers|date=3 April 2007|language=Ukrainian| accessdate= 5 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
The legality and authority of the President's determination to dismiss Ukraine's previous parliament has been the subject of a challenge in Ukraine's Constitutional Court.
On 30 April 2007 On the eve of the Court’s ruling on the legality of the President's decrees, Viktor Yushcheko intervened in the operation and independence of Ukraine's Constitutional Court by dismissing three Constitutional Court judges. The President's actions were later determined by Ukrainian courts of have been illegal and one of the judges dismissed has been reinstated; the other two judges resigned. Following the President's intervention the Constitutional Court has not ruled on the legality of the previous parliament's dismissal.
[[File:VerkhovnaRada April 11 2007.JPG|thumb|Meeting of [[Verkhovna Rada]] on 11 April 2007: the empty seats to the left are allocated for the Opposition.]]
In a separate issue, some politicians have claimed that [[Smart card|identification cards]] for voting changed hands,<ref name="bourse">{{cite web|url=http://www.unian.net/rus/news/news-189312.html|title=Verhovna Rada become a bourse?|publisher=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|date=27 March 2007|language=Russian| accessdate= 6 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> as many deputies do not attend parliament in violation of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 84|Article 84]] of the Constitution.<ref name="Akhmetov">{{cite news|url=http://www.pravda.com.ua/ru/news/2006/10/27/48627.htm|title=Akhmetov. "Ukrainian Berluskoni", which does not present|first=Victor|last=Chuvokunya|publisher=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]|date=27 October 2006|language=Russian| accessdate= 6 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}} Story on how Akhmetov card was voting.</ref>
The [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine|Central Election Commission]] has estimated direct costs of the elections to be at about 340 million UAH ($67 million, £34 million).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://5tv.com.ua/newsline/266/0/39255/ |title=On unscheduled elections needed 340 millions hryvnias.- Y. Davydovych |publisher=[[Kanal 5 (Ukraine)|Kanal 5]] |date=3 April 2007 |language=Ukrainian |accessdate=6 April 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410125335/http://5tv.com.ua/newsline/266/0/39255/ |archivedate=10 April 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Official rate UAH/USD = 5.05</ref><ref name="285/2007">{{cite web|url=http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/5980.html|title=On social-political situation and immediate actions on securing constitutional rights of Ukraine citizens|work=Decision of Council of National Security and Defense of Ukraine|date=6 April 2007|language=Ukrainian| accessdate= 6 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070410035044/http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/5980.html| archivedate= 10 April 2007| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Yulia Tymoshenko]], leader of the parliamentary opposition, commented on the issue of costs:<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-ukraine4apr04,1,5329442.story?coll=la-headlines-world|title=Ukraine president presses early election, warns against violence|first=David|last=Holley|author2=Sergei L. Loiko|date=4 April 2007|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]| accessdate= 4 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{quote|If the mafia is allowed to continue ruling the country, Ukraine will lose tens of billions of dollars, because Ukraine is being robbed today. | Yulia Tymoshenko}}
==Political crisis== The [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] is examining an inquiry submitted by a group of 53 members of parliament who question the constitutional legitimacy of the parliament's dissolution. This inquiry is based on interpretation that the President had no authority under Ukraine's constitution to dissolve parliament under the conditions listed in Article [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 90|90]]<ref name="constitution">{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/home/RSDLEGAL/44a280124.pdf|format=PDF|title=Constitution of Ukraine (with 2004 amendments)|publisher=[[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|UNHCR]]|date=8 December 2004|pages=27–28| accessdate= 6 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}} Unofficial translation.</ref> of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].<ref name="837-16"/> which is the only article in Ukraine's Constitution that empowers the President to dismiss Ukraine's Parliament.<ref name="Justice_expertise">{{cite web|url=http://www.minjust.gov.ua/0/9214 |title=Results of legal expertise of President order N 264 from 2 April 2007 |first=Oleksandr |last=Lavrynovych |publisher=Ministry of Justice of Ukraine |language=Ukrainian |accessdate=6 April 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070427200213/http://www.minjust.gov.ua/0/9214 |archivedate=27 April 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> Instead, the decree mentions Articles [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 5|5]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 69|69]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 77|77]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 83|83]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 102|102]], and [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 106|106]].<ref name="order_264/2007"/>
On 4 April, [[Ivan Dombrovskyy]], the Chairman of the Constitutional Court, filed for resignation, stating that he is under pressure. However, the judges rejected it.
On 5 April, Yanukovych has announced that during telephone conversation asked the [[Austria]]n [[Chancellor of Austria|Chancellor]] [[Alfred Gusenbauer]] to mediate in the dispute.<ref name="PM_mediate">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6529851.stm |title=Ukraine PM asks Austria to help |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=5 April 2007 |accessdate=6 April 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426235017/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6529851.stm |archivedate=26 April 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> There was no immediate response from Gusenbauer's office, and Austrian diplomats were surprised by the news about his help request.<ref name="mediate_response">{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20070406/wl_afp/ukrainepolitics|title=Rival Ukraine leaders hold crisis talks as deadlock persists|first=Olga|last=Nedbayeva|publisher=Yahoo News|date=6 April 2007| accessdate= 8 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
On 6 April, the [[Alliance of National Unity]] tried to compromise by dismissing the individuals from opposition fractions who had joined them and ratifying a parliamentary law banning individual membership in coalitions.<ref name="individuals_compromise">{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-04/07/content_5945535.htm|title=Ukrainian parliament makes compromise with president|date=7 April 2007|publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency|Xinhua]]| accessdate= 8 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
Four members of Central Election Commission - Yuriy Donchenko, Ihor Kachur, Bronislav Raykovskyy, and Oleksandr Chupakhin (reportedly affiliated with the Anti-Crisis Coalition) took sickness leave - thus effectively blocked work of commission as there is no [[quorum]].<ref name="sick">{{cite news|url=http://www.kommersant.ua/doc.html?docId=757551|title=Listing clocks|date=10 April 2007|author=Vycheslav Sirman|author2=Mustafa Naiem|publisher=[[Kommersant|Kommersant-Ukraine]]| accessdate= 10 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
As of 6 April in Constitutional Court, there are constitutional legitimacy questions from the President on an order of the Cabinet Ministers supporting the Verkhovna Rada and from 102 deputies on changes done to constitution in 2004.<ref name="court_status">{{cite web|url=http://www.ccu.gov.ua/pls/wccu/p004?lang=0&rej=0&pf6031=134|title=Status of 72 questions asked|work=Official Constitutional Court of Ukraine website|date=6 April 2007|format=DOC|language=Ukrainian|accessdate=6 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070717074854/http://www.ccu.gov.ua/pls/wccu/p004?lang=0&rej=0&pf6031=134|archive-date=17 July 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 7 April, [[Feodosiya]] city court has canceled own order from 5 April that originally disallowed to start elections.<ref name="feodosiya_copy">{{cite web|url=http://www.byut.com.ua/ukr/news-3430 |title=Feodosiya city court cancel own decision from April 5. Documents copy |work=[[Yulia Tymoshenko Electoral Bloc|BYuT]] website |date=7 April 2007 |language=Ukrainian |accessdate=8 April 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410122822/http://byut.com.ua/ukr/news-3430 |archivedate=10 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Vladimir Kolesnichenko, a spokesperson for the Party of Regions has said that this court ruling is a fake and that the elections are still banned.<ref name="feodosiya_fake">{{cite news|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=11412955|title=Ukraine's Regions Party says Feodossia court ruling a fake|date=7 April 2007|publisher=[[Information Telegraph Agency of Russia|ITAR TASS]]| accessdate= 10 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
On 9 April, the Rada has passed a declaration, stating:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://portal.rada.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article/news_left?art_id=91250&cat_id=37486|title=To the Heads of States, Governments and Parliaments of the European countries, Guarantor-States of the security of Ukraine, inter-State and inter-Parliamentary organizations|publisher=Verkhovna Rada official website|date=9 April 2007| accessdate= 10 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{quote|Via his entourage and the political circles he relies on, the President of Ukraine interferes with the activities of legislators, brings pressure on judges of Constitutional Court and other courts, since in the legal dimension he does not have any chance to defend his unconstitutional decree. | 2007 Rada declaration}}
Furthermore, the Rada called upon the heads of European states, governments, and parliaments to send its representatives to mediate the political crisis.
Ukraine's parliament on 9 April, raising the stakes in the country's ongoing political confrontation, stated <ref name="simultaneous-presidential-parliament-elections ">{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/04/09/europe/EU-POL-Ukraine-Politics.php|title=parliament calls for early presidential elections|date=9 April 2007|publisher=[[internatal Herald Tribune|IHT]]| accessdate= 22 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> that it would only support early parliamentary elections a presidential vote is held at the same time.
On 10 April, a [[Luhansk]] municipal courts' ruling, dated 6 April, banning all preparations for the election was publicly announced. The ruling was a response to an inquiry, submitted by Vladimir Ivanov, a Party of Regions member of parliament. Reportedly, this ruling was canceled.<ref name="lugansk_cancel">{{cite web|url=http://www.unian.net/rus/news/news-191312.html|title=Lugansk court follow Feodosiya footsteps|publisher=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|language=Russian|date=10 April 2007| accessdate= 10 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Ivanov has attempted to use labor laws in order to keep his deputy mandate:<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ll-media.info/cgi-bin/viewnws.cgi?nws=200704101305|title=Lugansk court was using labor law in order to ban election|date=10 April 2007|publisher=Parallel-Media|language=Russian|accessdate=10 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006122805/http://ll-media.info/cgi-bin/viewnws.cgi?nws=200704101305|archive-date=6 October 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
{{quote|I have concluded the employment contract for fixed term, and the President’s decree leaves me and my colleagues without work. This is roughest violation of the labor laws. | Vladimir Ivanov}}
Five [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine#List of judges|Constitutional Court judges]] (Dmytro Lelak, Volodymyr Kampo, Viktor Shyshkin, Petro Stetsyuk, Yaroslava Machuzhak), three of whom were appointed under the presidential quota, refused to participate in review of president order unless they will be given protection by law enforcement. They noted that "certain political forces, acting through their representatives, publicly apply rude pressure on the individual judges and on the Constitutional Court as a whole." <ref name="5_judges_pressure">{{cite web|url=http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-191396.html|title=Five Constitutional Court judges refuse to take part in considering President’s decree|publisher=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|date=10 April 2007| accessdate= 10 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
On 12–13 April, both Yanukovych and Yushchenko agreed to abide by the Court's ruling, regardless of its verdict.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=11427406&PageNum=0|title=Yushchenko to agree to any Constitutional Court ruling|publisher=[[ITAR TASS]]|date=12 April 2007| accessdate= 17 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=11429833&PageNum=0|title=Yanukovich ready for any constitutional court judgment|publisher=[[ITAR TASS]]|date=13 April 2007| accessdate= 17 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Furthermore, Yanukovych stated he might agree to parliamentary elections, if the other parties would also agree to participate, even if the Court rules in favor of the Rada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=143410&version=1&template_id=39&parent_id=21|title=Ukraine premier signals readiness for early polls|date=13 May 2007|publisher=[[Gulf Times]]|accessdate=13 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930201202/http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=143410&version=1&template_id=39&parent_id=21|archive-date=30 September 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 17 April, Ukraine's Constitutional Court, with all 18 judges in attendance, decided to study the appeal against the President's decree non-stop until a final ruling is passed. 11 out of 18 Judges passed this decision.
Ukrainian opposition leader Yulia Tymoshenko described a Constitutional Court decision to review the President's decree dissolving parliament as "a farce," and urged the president to recall the judges appointed on his quota.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20070417/63826764.html |title=Ukraine opposition says Constitutional Court 'a farce' |publisher=[[RIAN]] |date=17 April 2007 |accessdate=20 April 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070419142016/http://en.rian.ru/world/20070417/63826764.html |archivedate=19 April 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
The Court has yet to make its decision on the appeal, and is scheduled to announce it on 27 April.
[[File:Палатки возле Кабмина.jpg|thumb|Tent camp of [[Alliance of National Unity]] supporters near the building of the [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|government]].]]
Ukrainian Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych address Council of Europe Parliamentary Assembly stating that the coalition of the majority in Ukraine biggest concern is not that of elections, but the choice between whether Ukraine will be a state ruled by law and all of the emerging problems will be resolved in courts, or on the streets.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=11443333&PageNum=0|title=In Ukraine there no real grounds for a political crisis or early elections|publisher=[[ITAR-TASS]]|date=17 April 2007| accessdate= 22 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
Although 17 April was the deadline under established law to submit documents to the Central Election Commission for the registration of party lists, no political force has done so.
===Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe=== On 19 April, the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] held an emergency session to consider issues related to Ukraine's current political crisis. The Assembly passed a resolution calling on all parties to disputation to respect the decision of Ukraine's Constitutional Court whilst criticizing Ukraine's Constitution [[Imperative mandate (provision in the Constitution of Ukraine)|Imperative mandate]] provisions.<ref name="pace_1549">{{cite web|url=http://assembly.coe.int/Mainf.asp?link=/Documents/AdoptedText/ta07/ERES1549.htm |title=Functioning of democratic institutions in Ukraine -Resolution 1549 (2007) |publisher=[[Council of Europe]] |date=19 April 2007 |accessdate=20 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116103456/http://assembly.coe.int/Mainf.asp?link=%2FDocuments%2FAdoptedText%2Fta07%2FERES1549.htm |archivedate=16 November 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="pace_11255">{{cite web|url=http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=/Documents/WorkingDocs/Doc07/EDOC11255.htm |title=Functioning of democratic institutions in Ukraine(Doc 11255) |publisher=[[Council of Europe]] |date=19 April 2007 |accessdate=21 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705000656/http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=%2FDocuments%2FWorkingDocs%2FDoc07%2FEDOC11255.htm |archivedate=5 July 2007 |df= }}</ref>
Parliamentary Assembly rapporteurs on Ukraine - Hanne Severinsen and Renate Wohlwend commented:<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.coe.int/t/dc/files/pa_session/april_2007/20070419_news_ukraine_en.asp|title=All sides should accept the ruling of Ukraine’s Constitutional Court, says Parliamentary Assembly|publisher=[[Council of Europe]]|date=19 April 2007| accessdate= 24 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{quote|The ruling of Ukraine’s Constitutional Court in the current crisis, if delivered, should be accepted as binding by all sides, the Parliamentary Assembly said in a resolution adopted on 19 April at the end of an urgent debate attended by Ukraine’s Parliamentary Speaker Oleksandr Moroz. However, the Assembly also warned that pressure in any form on the judges of the Court was ''intolerable'', and should be investigated and criminally prosecuted. | Hanne Severinsen and Renate Wohlwend}}
The "imperative mandate" provision of Ukraine's Constitution came under strong criticism by the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] as being undemocratic.<ref name="PACE_report"/> The Parliamentary Assembly in its Explanatory memorandum had emphasized{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
{{quote|Although Ukraine understandably has its own historic reasons to avoid the accumulation of power into the hands of one political force, it should nevertheless consider in the course of future constitutional amendments whether it would not be better for the country to switch to a full parliamentary system with proper checks and balances and guarantees of parliamentary opposition and competition. | Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe}}
===Opposition Members First Resignations=== On 20 April, leaders of Bloc Yulia Tymoshenko and Our Ukraine have declared that about 150 deputy members of Our Ukraine and Bloc Yulia Tymoshenko have resigned from Ukraine's parliament, as result it claimed that the parliament will be no longer able to operate constitutionally per [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 82|Article 82]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://jamestown.org/edm/article.php?article_id=2372110|title=Our Ukraine and Viktor Yushchenko revive their fortunes|first=Taras|last=Kuzio|date=19 April 2007|publisher=[[Jamestown Foundation]]|accessdate=21 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070915164643/http://www.jamestown.org/edm/article.php?article_id=2372110|archive-date=15 September 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Their resignations have been submitted to Vikor Yushchenko, Ukraine's President, who has accepted their resignation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.en.for-ua.com/news/2007/04/20/164131.html |title=Yushchenko approved opposition people’s deputies resignation |date=20 April 2007 |publisher=[[for-ua]] |accessdate=22 April 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070427083800/http://en.for-ua.com/news/2007/04/20/164131.html |archivedate=27 April 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
Dmitry Vydrin from the Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko (BYuT), has declared that he had not written an application on abdication, as nobody has not made this request. According to him, “there are three reasons” why he did not give his mandate, reports Delo. “At first, nobody addressed to me with my proposal. Nobody phoned me and told me to write down this application. So how could I write it?” declared the deputy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mignews.com.ua/en/articles/251776.html|title=Conflict in BYT! Tymoshenko is to Make Choice|publisher=[[MigNews]]|date=20 April 2007|accessdate=20 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109055641/http://mignews.com.ua/en/articles/251776.html|archive-date=9 November 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.zik.com.ua/index.php?news_id=80546|title=It was told holops to withdrew their mandates. I am also obedient, even though I'm a truthful holop myself.|first=Dmitry|last=Vydrin|date=18 April 2007|language=Ukrainian| accessdate= 21 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
[[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]], Poland's former [[President of Poland|President]], believes that Ukraine must find a political compromise and solution to the current political crisis facing Ukraine. When asked who is to blame he responded:<ref>{{cite news|url=http://weekly.com.ua/?rub=news&from=0&page=0&ncode=1177089585#open_news|title=Kwasniewski unveils Yushchenko's proposal to Yanukovych|publisher=[[Kyiv Weekly]]|date=20 April 2007| accessdate= 23 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
{{quote|Unfortunately, the time after the Orange Revolution was wasted away. President Yushchenko, [the former] Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko, advisers like Petro Poroshenko are all to blame. They should have helped building a strong orange bloc, for the sake of modernization and Westernization of Ukraine. | Aleksander Kwaśniewski}}
On 25 April, Viktor Yushchenko announced that he has rescheduled the early parliamentary elections to 24 June.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200704/s1906630.htm |title=Ukraine delays parliamentary poll |publisher=ABC News Online |date=26 April 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070528052737/http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200704/s1906630.htm |archivedate=28 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> On 30 April, the Rada passed a motion calling for presidential and parliamentary elections to be held on 9 December 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.monstersandcritics.com/europe/news/article_1298293.php/Ukraine_parliament_sets_own_election_date_Yushchenko_stands_firm|title=Ukraine parliament sets own election date, Yushchenko stands firm|publisher=Monsters and Critics|date=30 April 2007|accessdate=30 April 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929131335/http://news.monstersandcritics.com/europe/news/article_1298293.php/Ukraine_parliament_sets_own_election_date_Yushchenko_stands_firm|archive-date=29 September 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> After negotiations on 4 May, Yanukovych and Yushchenko finally agreed to hold elections in autumn (without specifying a date).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6624737.stm |title=Ukraine rivals agree early poll |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=4 May 2007 |accessdate=4 May 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513133231/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6624737.stm |archivedate=13 May 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Dismissal of Constitutional Court judges and Prosecutor General==
===Constitutional Court=== The authority of the President to dismiss Ukraine's parliament was challenged in Ukraine's Constitutional Court amidst concern that the President's actions were unconstitutional in that he had exceeded his authority to dismiss Ukraine's parliament.<ref name="Ministry of Justice Legal Opinion">{{cite web |url=http://www.minjust.gov.ua/files/The_Legal_Opinion_of_the_Ministry_of_Justice.rtf |title=Legal Opinion with regard to the results of legal examination of Decree of the President of Ukraine dated April, 2 the year 2007 N 264 "On pre-term abatement of authority of the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine" |publisher=Ministry of Justice Ukraine |format=DOC |accessdate=26 August 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927225907/http://www.minjust.gov.ua/files/The_Legal_Opinion_of_the_Ministry_of_Justice.rtf |archivedate=27 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
An appeal against each of the president's decrees was lodged in the Constitutional Court.
* On 19 April the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe passed a resolution in consideration of a report titled Functioning of democratic institutions in Ukraine. <sup>(Items 13 and 14)</sup> <ref name="PACE_1549">
{{cite web |url=http://assembly.coe.int/Mainf.asp?link=/Documents/AdoptedText/ta07/ERES1549.htm |title=Functioning of democratic institutions in Ukraine |author=PACE |publisher=[[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] |date=19 April 2007 |authorlink=Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe |accessdate=20 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116103456/http://assembly.coe.int/Mainf.asp?link=%2FDocuments%2FAdoptedText%2Fta07%2FERES1549.htm |archivedate=16 November 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> stated: {{Cquote|The Assembly deplores the fact that the judicial system of Ukraine has been systematically misused by other branches of power and that top officials do not execute the courts’ decisions, which is a sign of erosion of this crucial democratic institution. An independent and impartial judiciary is a precondition for the existence of a democratic society governed by the rule of law. Hence the urgent necessity to carry out comprehensive judicial reform, including through amendments to the constitution. The Assembly reiterates that the authority of the sole body responsible for constitutional justice – the Constitutional Court of Ukraine – should be guaranteed and respected. Any form of pressure on the judges is intolerable and should be investigated and criminally prosecuted. On the other hand, it is regrettable that in the eight months of its new full composition, the Constitutional Court has failed to produce judgments, thus failing to fulfill its constitutional role and to contribute to resolving the crisis in its earlier stages, which undermines the credibility of the court. There is an urgent need for all pending judgments, and in particular the judgment concerning the constitutionality of the Presidential Decree of 2 April 2007, to be delivered. If delivered, the latter should be accepted as binding by all sides.}}
The associated explanatory report under the sub-heading of '''''Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe - Resolution 1549 (2007) Functioning of democratic institutions in Ukraine''''' expressed concern that {{Cquote|"Several local courts have made decisions to suspend the Presidential Decree only to then withdraw them, allegedly under pressure from the presidential secretariat." <sup>(item 67)</sup>}}
In emphasis the report <sup>(item 68)</sup> stated {{Cquote|This is a worrying tendency of legal nihilism that should not be tolerated. It is as clear as day that in a state governed by the rule of law judicial mistakes should be corrected through appeal procedures and not through threats or disciplinary sanctions}}
* On 30 April, on the eve of the Constitutional Court's ruling on the legality of the president's decree dismissing Ukraine's parliament, President Yushchenko, in defiance of the PACE resolution of 19 April intervened in the operation of Ukraine's Constitutional Court by summarily dismissing two Constitutional Court Judges, Syuzanna Stanik and [[Valeriy Pshenychnyy]], for allegations of "oath treason."<ref name="eng.for-ua.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.eng.for-ua.com/news/2007/05/03/103007.html|title=Yushchenko dismissed CCU judges|accessdate=17 May 2006|work=for-ua |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929103211/http://www.eng.for-ua.com/news/2007/05/03/103007.html |archivedate = 29 September 2007}}</ref> His move was later overturned by the Constitutional Court and the judges were returned by a [[Injunction|temporary restraining order]] issued by the court.<ref name="korrespondent">{{cite news|url=http://www.korrespondent.net/main/190075 |title=Stanik and Pshenychnyy returned to CC |date=17 May 2007 |publisher=[[Korrespondent]] |accessdate=25 May 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070517061140/http://www.korrespondent.net/main/190075 |archivedate=17 May 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> * On 16 May,Viktor Yushchenko, for a second time, issued another decree dismissing the two Constitutional Court Judges Syuzanna Stanik and [[Valeriy Pshenychnyy]].<ref name="korrespondent2">{{cite news|url=http://pravda.com.ua/news/2007/5/16/58814.htm|title=Stanik and Pshenychnyy again became ex-judges of Constitutional Court|accessdate=17 May 2006|date=16 May 2007|work=[[Korrespondent]]}}</ref> * On 17 May, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine|Constitutional Court]] Chairman [[Ivan Dombrovskyy]] resigned and [[Valeriy Pshenychnyy]] was appointed chairman in replacement. * On 23 May, The Constitutional Court of Ukraine acted to prevent the president's undue influence on the court system.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/index.php?id=148&listid=45930 |title=Constitutional Court of Ukraine restricts president's influence on courts |publisher=Ukrainian National Radio |date=23 May 2007 |accessdate=24 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928014407/http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/index.php?id=148&listid=45930 |archivedate=28 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> The court's ruling was made after Viktor Yushchenko unduly sought to influence the court by illegally dismissing two Constitutional Court judges [[Valeriy Pshenychnyy]] and Syuzanna Stanik for allegations of "oath treason."<ref name="eng.for-ua.com"/>
Pursuant to [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 149|Article 149]] of Ukraine's Constitution Judges of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine are subject to the guarantees of independence and immunity and to the grounds for dismissal from office envisaged by [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 126|Article 126]], and the requirements concerning incompatibility as determined in [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 127|Article 127]], paragraph two of Ukraine's Constitution
* On 20 July Susanna Stanik won an appeal against the President in the Shevchenko district court of Kiev. The Court ruled the President's actions illegal and reinstated Ms Stanik's entitlement as a member of Ukraine's Constitutional Court. According to the ruling, the President is obliged to cancel his decree on discharge of Mrs. Stanik."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pravda.com.ua/en/news/2007/7/20/8377.htm |title=Stanik Back Into the CC |accessdate=20 July 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930222936/http://www.pravda.com.ua/en/news/2007/7/20/8377.htm |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> The other two judges who were also illegally dismissed had previously tendered their resignations and as such were not subject to the courts order.
Following the president's intervention the Constitutional Court still has not ruled on the question of legality of the president's actions.
Stepan Havrysh, the President's appointee to the Constitutional Court, in prejudgment of the court's decision and without authorization from the Court itself, commented in an interview published on 24 July {{Cquote|I cannot imagine myself as the Constitutional Court in condition in which three political leaders signed a political/legal agreement on holding early elections, which also stipulates the constitutional basis for holding the elections... How the court can agree to consider such a petition under such conditions.<ref name="Ukranews">{{cite web|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/56286.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130105065756/http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/56286.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-05 |title=Constitutional Court Judge Havrysh Doubts Constitutional Court Will Consider Petition On Constitutionality Of September 30 Rada Elections |publisher=Ukrainian News agency |date=2007-07-24 |accessdate=26 August 2007 }}</ref>}}
Oleksandr Lavrynovych, Ukrainian Minister for Justice, in an interview published on 3 August is quoted as saying {{Cquote|According to the standards of the Constitution and the laws of Ukraine, these elections should have been recognized invalid already today. But we understand that we speak about the State and about what will happen further in this country. As we've understood, political agreements substitute for the law, ... The situation has been led to the limit, where there are no possibilities to follow all legal norms.<ref name="Lavrynovych">{{cite web|url=http://en.for-ua.com/news/2007/08/03/161518.html |title=Lavrynovych: Early elections should have been already recognized invalid today |publisher=Inter-Media, ForUm |date=2007-08-03 |accessdate=26 August 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929102952/http://en.for-ua.com/news/2007/08/03/161518.html |archivedate=29 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>}}
* On 25 March 2008 Ukraine's Supreme Administrative Court ruled the President's dismissal of Suzanna Stanik as a Constitutional Court judge illegal. Ms Stanik's position has been reinstated. The decision is final and not subject to further appeal <ref name="Ukranews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/112528.html |title=Supreme Court Restores Stanik As Constitutional Court Judge |publisher=Ukrainian News agency |date=27 March 2008 |accessdate=27 March 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509123552/http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/112528.html |archivedate=9 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Prosecutor General=== [[File:Piskun breaking into his office in Kiev, Ukraine.jpg|thumb|Recently dismissed [[Office of public prosecutor of Ukraine|Prosecutor General of Ukraine]] [[Svyatoslav Piskun]] breaking into his office, surrounded by Members of the State Protection Department on 24 May 2007.]]
On 24 May, Yushchenko fired the [[Office of public prosecutor of Ukraine|Prosecutor General of Ukraine]], [[Svyatoslav Piskun]], who was appointed by Yushchenko himself on 26 April, after Piskun refused to resign his place in the Verkhovna Rada as was required by the [[Constitution of Ukraine|Ukrainian law]], so as to not hold two positions at the same time. Yushchenko cited Constitution Article [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 78|78]] which states "Where there emerge circumstances infringing requirements concerning the incompatibility of the deputy’s mandate with other types of activity, the People’s Deputy of Ukraine shall within twenty days from the date of the emergence of such circumstances discontinue such activity or lodge a personal application for divesting of People’s Deputy authority" and Item 1 of Article 3 of Law № 2783-IV<ref name="2783-IV">{{Cite Ukrainian law|type=Presidential Decree|law=357/2007|name= On peculiarities of firing the persons who combine deputy mandate with other types of activity|date=8 July 2005}}</ref> when issuing his decree on the dismissal of the Prosecutor General.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/data/1_16063.html|title=President comments on Piskun's sacking|date=24 May 2006|work=[[President of Ukraine]]|accessdate=25 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108133917/http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/data/1_16063.html|archive-date=8 January 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The President appointed Viktor Shemchuk, the Prosecutor General of Crimea, as a replacement to Svyatoslav Piskun.<ref name="kommersant-05-24">{{cite web|url=http://www.kommersant.com/p768566/Ukraine_crisis|title=Ukrainian State in Meltdown|date=24 May 2006|work=[[Kommersant]]| accessdate= 25 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> After Piskun's dismissal, thousands of protesters marched to his office in Kiev protesting his dismissal. Piskun, accompanied by several deputies from the [[Party of Regions]], tried to enter his office in Kiev, however, were prevented from doing so by the Members of the State Protection Department, with Valeriy Heletiy at their lead.<ref name="kommersant-05-24"/> Valeriy Heletiy and the deputies were later joined by the [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist Party]] leader [[Petro Symonenko]] and supporters of the Party of Regions.<ref name="kommersant-05-24"/> The [[Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine|Minister of Internal Affairs of Ukraine]], [[Vasyl Tsushko]], ordered Ukraine's [[Berkut (Ukraine)|Berkut]] [[riot police]] to surround the building, defying Yushchenko's order for the Ukrainian security services not to get involved in the political conflict.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=11562358&PageNum=0|title=Ukraine’s Yushchenko tells police,military to stay out of politics|publisher=[[ITAR-TASS]]|date=23 May 2007| accessdate= 24 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Tsushko responded to Yushchenko's dismissal of Piskun as a "[[coup d'état]]."<ref name="kommersant-05-24"/>
On 25 May, Viktor Yushchenko ordered a decree,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/6190.html |title=On the system of control of the interior ministry troops with the Constitution of Ukraine |publisher=[[President of Ukraine]] |date=25 May 2007 |accessdate=25 May 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070527115721/http://www.president.gov.ua/documents/6190.html |archivedate=27 May 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> taking control over 40,000 interior ministry troops.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6691371.stm |title=Ukraine leaders spar over troops |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=25 May 2007 |accessdate=25 May 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070608072925/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6691371.stm |archivedate=8 June 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> Meanwhile, the troops were acting on orders of the Interior Minister of Ukraine Vasyl Tsushko, who was charged with abuse of office on 25 May.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=11566267&PageNum=0|title=Ukraine’s Ukrainian interior minister charged with abuse of office|publisher=[[ITAR-TASS]]|date=25 May 2007| accessdate= 25 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
On 26 May, thousands of Interior Ministry troops moved towards Ukraine's capital [[Kiev]] on the President's orders.<ref name="bloomberg-05-16">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601085&sid=a_r6ZboYQo7E&refer=europe|title=Ukraine's Interior Ministry Troops Moving Toward Kiev|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=26 May 2007| accessdate= 26 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The troops were only lightly armed with [[riot gear]] and no lethal weapons. On their way to Kiev, the troops were stopped by Ukrainian Traffic Police.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2007/05/26/ukraine_rivals_hold_talks_troops_deployed_to_kiev/ |title=Ukraine rivals hold talks, troops deployed to Kiev |publisher=[[Boston Globe]] |date=26 May 2007 |accessdate=26 May 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070528084504/http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2007/05/26/ukraine_rivals_hold_talks_troops_deployed_to_kiev/ |archivedate=28 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Deputy Interior Minister Mykhailo Kornienko stated that about 2,050 troops from 13 out of 25 of Ukrainian [[oblast]]s were deployed.<ref name="bloomberg-05-16"/> According to the Vice Commander of the Interior Ministry troops Mykola Mishakin, about 3,480 troops were deployed near Kiev.<ref name="korrespondent-05-26">{{cite news|url=http://www.korrespondent.net/main/191962|title=Interior Ministry troops walk to Kiev. They have no lethal weapons.|publisher=[[Korrespondent]]|date=26 May 2007|language=Russian| accessdate= 26 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Since their entrance into the capital was blocked by [[Berkut (Ukraine)|Berkut]] and the Government Automobile Inspection, the Interior Ministry troops would walk to Kiev.<ref name="korrespondent-05-26"/> Mykola Mishakin stated:<ref name="korrespondent-05-26"/>
{{Cquote|We will be here as long as it takes so that bloodshed will not occur... and where ever it takes so that there will be no use of force, and to give the politicians a chance to resolve their problems in a peaceful and human way.}}
After over seven hours of discussions, Yushchenko, Yanukovych, and the Verkhovna Rada [[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] have come to an agreement by setting the date for [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|new parliamentary elections]] on 30 September 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.korrespondent.net/main/191968|title=Results of Yushchenko's meeting: new parliamentary elections will be held on September 30|publisher=[[Korrespondent]]|date=27 May 2007|language=Russian| accessdate= 27 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
After coming to a compromise on an election date, the Verkhovna Rada was given two days to accept the new elections and legally prepare for them.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=11555&sectionid=3510206|title=Ukraine constitutional crisis continues|publisher=Press TV|date=31 May 2007| accessdate= 31 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> The [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]] adopted a bill that would allow funding for the early parliamentary elections,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Top_News/2007/05/30/ukrainian_early_election_funding_endorsed/3754/|title=Ukrainian early election funding endorsed|publisher=United Press International|date=30 May 2007|accessdate=31 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080114191632/http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Top_News/2007/05/30/ukrainian_early_election_funding_endorsed/3754/|archive-date=14 January 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and the Rada approved the necessary laws on 1 June 2007.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6714113.stm | work=BBC News | title=Ukrainian MPs approve snap poll | date=1 June 2007 | accessdate=22 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420230758/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6714113.stm| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Yushchenko formally called the election on 5 June 2007, thus ending the political crisis.<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2007/06/b23f1f48-285c-422b-822e-b03d5f694f3c.html Ukrainian President Formally Sets Early-Election Date - RADIO FREE EUROPE / RADIO LIBERTY]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Wikinews|Wikinews_Shorts: 2 April 2007#Yushchenko calls early elections in Ukraine|Yushchenko calls early elections in Ukraine}} * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6519951.stm BBC news] — Ukraine leader calls early poll * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071116103456/http://assembly.coe.int/Mainf.asp?link=%2FDocuments%2FAdoptedText%2Fta07%2FERES1549.htm Council of Europe] — resolution on Ukrainian Crisis * [http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=/Documents/WorkingDocs/Doc07/EDOC11255.htm Council of Europe] — Explanatory memorandum * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061127211741/http://www.venice.coe.int/site/dynamics/N_Country_ef.asp?C=47&L=E Council of Europe] — Venice Commission:Ukraine

In U.S. food regulations, an '''Acceptable Market Name''' is a set of guidelines for names of [[seafood]] sold in [[interstate commerce]].
The Acceptable Market Names are recommendations, and not legally enforceable.

{{primarysources|date=June 2009}} The '''American Freedom Campaign''' is an organization that has as its goal to put restoration of the Constitution on the agenda for Democratic presidential candidates, roughly parallel to the goal of the [[American Freedom Agenda]] for Republican candidates, although Democratic and Republican candidates could sign on to both pledges. It was launched in July 2007 by the [[Center for Constitutional Rights]], [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[MoveOn]]. [https://news.yahoo.com/s/thenation/20070727/cm_thenation/1217965] The group urges presidential candidates to sign its "American Freedom Pledge", which reads:
We are Americans, and in our America we do not torture, we do not imprison people without charge or [[legal recourse]], allow our phones and emails to be tapped without a court order, and above all we do not give any President unchecked power. I pledge to fight to protect and defend the Constitution from assault by any President. The Constitution protects American Freedom. With checks and balances, and basic legal rights, it has prevented tyranny and safeguarded our liberty. Yet today, under the pretense of the "war on terror," the White House is dismantling the Constitution, concentrating power in the President and undermining the rule of law. THIS IS UN-AMERICAN. I hereby join the American Freedom Campaign to educate my neighbors about the threat and urge my representatives to confront and correct these abuses of our America.
AFC was co-founded by [[Naomi Wolf]], [[Wes Boyd]] and [[Human Genome Sciences|William Haseltine]].[http://www.frugalmarketing.com/dtb/2007bea-wolf.shtml] ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110714192108/http://afagenda.nonprofitsoapbox.com/ Official site] {{poli-org-stub}} [[Category:United States political action committees]] [[Category:527 organizations]]

'''Angary''' ([[Latin|Lat.]] ''jus angariae''; [[French language|Fr.]] ''droit d'angarie''; [[German language|Ger.]] ''Angarie''; from the [[Ancient Greek|Gr.]] {{lang|grc|ἀγγαρεία}}, ''angareia'', "the office of an {{lang|grc|ἄγγαρος}} ([[courier]] or messenger)") is the name given to the right of a belligerent (most commonly, a [[government]] or other party in conflict) to seize and apply for the purposes of [[war]] (or to prevent the enemy from doing so) any kind of property on belligerent territory, including that which may belong to subjects or citizens of a neutral state.
Article 53 of the Regulations respecting the Laws and Customs of War on Land, annexed to the [[Hague Conventions (1899 and 1907)|Hague Convention]] of 1899 on the same subject, provides that railway plant, land [[telegraph]]s, [[telephone]]s, [[Steamboat|steamers]] and other ships (other than such as are governed by [[maritime law]]), though belonging to companies or private persons, ''may be used'' for military operations, but "must be restored at the conclusion of peace ''and'' indemnities paid for them." Article 54 adds that "the plant of [[railway]]s coming from neutral states, whether the property of those states or of companies or private persons, shall be sent back to them as soon as possible."
These articles seem to sanction the right of angary against neutral property, while limiting it as against both belligerent and neutral property. It may be considered, however, that the right to use implies as wide a range of contingencies as the "necessity of war" can be made to cover.

{{distinguish|Blowing Up Russia}} {{Infobox film | name = Assassination of Russia | image = Assassination of Russia.jpg | alt = | caption = | film name = | director = | producer = Jean-Charles Deniau
Charles Gazelle | writer = | screenplay = | story = | based on = | starring = | narrator = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = | distributor = | released = {{film date|2002}} | runtime = | country = France | language = | budget = | gross = }} '''''Assassination of Russia''''' ({{lang-ru|Покушение на Россию}}) is a 2002 documentary film that describes the September 1999 [[Russian apartment bombings]] as a terrorism act committed by [[Federal Security Service (Russia)|Russian state security services]].[[Alexander Goldfarb (author)|Alex Goldfarb]] and Marina Litvinenko. "[[Death of a Dissident|Death of a Dissident: The Poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko and the Return of the KGB.]]" Free Press, New York, 2007. {{ISBN|978-1-4165-5165-2}}, pages 249-252[http://www.kommersant.com/p313379/r_1/Boris_Berezovsky_organized_Assassination_of_Russia/ Boris Berezovsky organized "Assassination of Russia"] The film was created in 2001 by French producers [[:fr:Jean-Charles Deniau|Jean-Charles Deniau]] and Charles Gazelle. [[Yuri Felshtinsky]] and [[Alexander Litvinenko]] worked as consultants for the film; the film was made on the basis of their book ''[[Blowing Up Russia: Terror from Within]]''. The French producers initially worked for Russian TV company [[NTV (Russia)|NTV]] to expand their program "Sugar of Ryazan" and later to [[TV-6 (Russia)|TV-6]]. When TV-6 channel was closed by Russian authorities, the film was 70% completed. The remaining funds were provided by [[Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|Boris Berezovsky]].{{Cite journal |title=A chapter from David Levy's work in progress "From Chaguanas to Jerusalem: Tribal Conflict in the Global Mosaic" |first=David |last= Levy |journal=The Montréal Review |date=April 2012 |url=http://www.themontrealreview.com/2009/Post-Soviet-Russia-Chechens-KGB-Khodorkovsky.php }} Leader of party ''Liberal Russia'', [[Sergei Yushenkov]] flew to the premier on March 5, 2002, in London, to announce that his party is going to distribute copies of the film around the country to demonstrate "how the secret services deceived Russian citizens". This film was broadcast by the main TV channels of [[Estonia]], [[Latvia]], and [[Lithuania]]. Russian [[State Duma]] Deputy [[Yuli Rybakov]] brought a hundred copies to St. Petersburg, but the copies were confiscated at customs in violation of his [[parliamentary immunity]]. No TV station in Russia was able to show the film. Tens of thousands of copies were sold in Russia in 2002. Sergei Yushenkov presented the film at the [[Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars]] in 2002, decrying lack of civilian control over the Russian armed forces including the secret services.[https://www.wilsoncenter.org/event/assassination-russia-film-screening-and-panel-discussion "Assassination of Russia"- Film Screening and Panel Discussion], [[Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars]], April 24, 2002 A staffer in [[Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] said, ''"We just cannot go out and say that the president of Russia is a mass murderer. But it is important that we know it."'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== *[[Rebellion: the Litvinenko Case]] ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0808157}} * {{YouTube|9sx2YmSXDy8|Assassination of Russia (Blowing up Russia)}} * {{YouTube|REy-oTEAxHk|Запрещенный Фильм "Покушение на Россию"}} {{Alexander Litvinenko}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Assassination Of Russia}} [[Category:French documentary films]] [[Category:Russian apartment bombings]] [[Category:2002 films]] [[Category:Documentary films about terrorism]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Chechen wars films]] [[Category:Works about the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation]] [[Category:Alexander Litvinenko]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Censorship in Russia]] [[Category:Deep politics]] {{France-documentary-film-stub}}

'''Bob Sang''' (27 March 1948 - 5 June 2009) was appointed by [[London South Bank University]] as the UK's first professor of Patient and Public Involvement in 2006.<ref>http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=407188&sectioncode=26</ref> He had also been a Visiting Fellow at [[CENTRIM]].<ref>http://centrim.mis.brighton.ac.uk/news/sang-memorial</ref>
He was educated at the [[University of East Anglia]] but failed his chemistry degree there. He later returned to studying and completed a public administration degree at the [[University of Sussex]].
He was a pioneer of the idea of involving patients, service users and the public in health and social care, describing himself as a 'constructive subversive'.<ref>http://www.healthpolicyinsight.com/?q=node/298</ref>
Sang was a prolific networker and writer, contributing articles<ref>https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?as_q=&num=10&as_epq=bob+sang&as_oq=&as_eq=&as_occt=any&as_sauthors=Bob+Sang&as_publication=&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&as_sdt=1&as_subj=bio&as_subj=med&as_subj=bus&as_subj=soc&as_sdts=5&btnG=Search+Scholar&hl=en</ref> to journals including ''Health Policy Insight'',<ref>http://www.healthpolicyinsight.com/?q=node/304</ref> ''British Journal of Healthcare Management'',<ref>http://www.bjhcm.co.uk</ref> the ''Journal of Integrated Care''<ref>https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?cluster=6670628938121356481&hl=en&as_sdt=2000</ref> and the ''[[Health Service Journal]]''.<ref>http://www.hsj.co.uk/bob-sang/1240.contributor</ref>
Following a career which combined academia, research and working in mental health, he established his own independent consultancy, Sang Jacobsson. His work through Sang Jacobsson included mentoring, training, policy work, facilitation and analysis, and was mainly for clients in the NHS and the UK health economy.
Sang was the co-founder with Jane Keep of the Engaging Communities Learning Network<ref>http://www.networks.nhs.uk/networks.php?pid=19</ref> for the National Association of Primary and Care Trusts (NatPaCT), which was part of the now-closed [[NHS Modernisation Agency]]. The Engaging Communities Learning Network was designed to help NHS [[primary care trust]]s (PCTs) share good practice and learning about patient and public involvement and engagement.
He provided professional supervision to the ground-breaking Health Foundation Leadership Fellows Scheme which over five years directly involved patients and users in the leadership development of 64 NHS clinicians and managers.
He died of [[acute pancreatitis]] on 5 June 2009.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2009/jul/02/bob-sang-obituary</ref>

'''Breakthrough Collaborative''' (formerly Summerbridge National) is the umbrella organization of a collaborative of programs across the United States and in Hong Kong that aim to effect positive change in [[Urban area|urban]] schools. Breakthrough offers high-potential, under-served [[middle school]] students the opportunity to participate in rigorous academic enrichment programs throughout the summer and school year. Students make a commitment to participate in the program through middle school and high school and in turn, Breakthrough provides many services to students and their families, ranging from academic enrichment to one-on-one tutoring to [[high school]] and [[college]] preparation. Additionally, all Breakthrough classes are taught by talented, high-achieving high school and college students from around the country who are interested in the field of education. Through the teacher development program offered by Breakthrough, these young educators become potential candidates for professional teaching and educational leadership positions after college. Teaching at Breakthrough has been named a Top Ten Internship in America by the [[Princeton Review]], as well as other prestigious national organizations, and a 1999 [[Stanford University]] report stated that "72% [of Breakthrough teachers] went on to work in other educationally related careers or internships after teaching at a Breakthrough site."
Breakthrough was founded in 1978 by Lois Loofbourrow at [[San Francisco University High School]]. Since then, numerous sites have opened, all in various sized urban areas. The sites are joined together under the umbrella organization, Breakthrough Collaborative, based in San Francisco. Sites function either through [[public-private partnership]]s with an independent educational institution or maintain their own 501(c)3 status.
Since its inception in 1978, Breakthrough programs around the world have generated thousands of student and teacher alums. In 2003, the Summerbridge/Breakthrough Alumni Network or SBAN was formed through the efforts of alumni. SBAN is based out of Atlanta, but holds annual conferences around the United States.
In March 2006, the 22 host schools of Breakthrough programs were awarded the Klingenstein Leadership Award by the Klingenstein Center at [[Teachers College, Columbia University]]. Breaking from the tradition of giving this prestigious award to an individual, 26 independent schools received the 2006 award. Past recipients include [[William Durden]], [[Diane Ravitch]], [[Robert Coles (psychiatrist)|Robert Coles]], and [[Howard Gardner]]. In 2007, the Johns Hopkins University Center for Summer Learning awarded Breakthrough Collaborative and its affiliate site in Pittsburgh, with the Excellence in Summer Learning Award for exemplary mission, performance, and infrastructure in out-of-school academic support.
'''Breakthrough''' at Hong Kong is called '''Summerbridge Hong Kong'''.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Summerbridge Hong Kong|url = http://www.summerbridge.org.hk|website = www.summerbridge.org.hk|accessdate = 2015-10-10}}</ref> Summerbridge Hong Kong is the only site outside of the United States. A key difference is that at Summerbridge Hong Kong, teachers teach self-designed topics with support from the Dean of Faculty. A typical day for a Summerbridge Hong Kong student consists of morning all-school meeting (ASM), classes in the morning, lunch with teachers, and extracurricular time.
