'''Serbian historiography''' ({{lang-sr|Српска историографија/Srpska istoriografija}}) refers to the historiography (methodology of history studies) of the [[Serb people]] since the founding of Serbian statehood. The development can be divided into four main stages: traditional historiography, Ruvarac's critical school, Communist–Marxist legacy, and the renewed Serbian national movement.{{sfn|Woolf|2014|p=825}}
== Modern Serbian historiography ==
[[Jovan Rajić]] (1726–1801) was the forerunner to modern Serbian historiography,<ref name="Boia1989">{{cite book|author=Lucian Boia|title=Great Historians from Antiquity to 1800: An International Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VrENAAAAIAAJ|date=1 January 1989|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=978-0-313-24517-6|page=343}}</ref> and has been compared to the importance of [[Nikolay Karamzin]] to [[Russian historiography]].<ref>{{cite book|author=University of Colorado|location=Boulder, Colorado|title=Journal of Central European Affairs|volume=16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u049AAAAIAAJ|year=1956|publisher=University of Colorado|page=23}}</ref> The foundations of Serbian ecclesiastical historiography were laid by Bishop [[Nikodim Milaš]] (1845–1915).<ref name="Perica72"/> [[Ilarion Ruvarac]] (1832–1905) is regarded the founder of the critical school of Serbian historiography.<ref>{{cite book|title=Serbian Studies|volume=45|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RnVpAAAAMAAJ|year=1986|publisher=North American Society for Serbian Studies|page=180|quote=Among these historians he points out the significance of Jovan Rajic (1726–1801) and Ilarion Ruvarac (1832–1905). The former indeed "stood on the threshold between the enlightenment and the age of romanticism" and later, as the principal representative and founder of the critical school of Serbian historiography, took "the first relatively objective look at ...}}</ref><ref name="FitzsimonsPundt1967">{{cite book|author1=Matthew Anthony Fitzsimons|author2=Alfred George Pundt|author3=Charles E. Nowell|title=The development of historiography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ea_vAAAAMAAJ|year=1967|publisher=Kennikat Press|page=348|quote=Ruvarac (1832–1905) belonged to the rigidly scientific, relentlessly analytic school of historiography which held that the sources must be ... the school of Ruvarac triumphed in the end, and by the early 1880's Serbian historiography was definitely founded in ...}}</ref> Ruvarac's school clashed with that of [[Panta Srećković]] (1834–1903).<ref name="HarrimanSalvadori1953">{{cite book|author1=Philip Lawrence Harriman|author2=Massimo Salvadori|title=Contemporary Social Science|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UzREAAAAIAAJ|year=1953|publisher=Stackpole Company|page=255}}</ref> Serbian historiography was mostly focused on national issues during the [[Society of Serbian Scholarship]] and [[Serbian Learned Society]] (1841–1886).<ref name="Stephenson2010">{{cite book|author=Paul Stephenson|title=The Byzantine World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M-SrAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA482|date=20 December 2010|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-72787-0|pages=482–}}</ref>
Serbian ecclesiastical historiography has coincided with nationalist perspectives contained within secular Serbian historiography.<ref name="Perica72">{{harvnb|Perica|2002|p=72.}}</ref> Orthodox Church tradition and early Serbian historiography through folk poetry based upon the Battle of Kosovo assisted in overcoming gaps and linking the old with the then new Serbian state.<ref name="Velikonja95">{{cite book|last=Velikonja|first=Mitja|title=Religious separation and political intolerance in Bosnia-Herzegovina|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rqjLgtYDKQ0C&pg=PA95&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islam&f=false|year=2003|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|isbn=978-1-60344-724-9|page=95|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Bennett160">{{cite book|last=Bennett|first=Matthew|chapter=The Kosovo Liberation Army|editor1-last=Bennett|editor1-first=Matthew|editor2-last=Latawski|editor2-first=Paul|title=Exile armies|year=2004|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-0-230-52245-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=OPhZCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA160&dq=Serbian+historians+Balkan+wars#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Balkan%20wars&f=false|page=160|ref=harv}}</ref> The nation and religion were closely connected within nationalist Serbian history in the early 19th century.<ref name="Deringil6">{{cite book|last=Deringil|first=Selim|title=Conversion and apostasy in the late Ottoman Empire|url=https://books.google.com/?id=z0wgAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA6&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islam&f=false|year=2012|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-51048-6|page=6|ref=harv}}</ref> Patriotic historiography viewed the Serbs as liberators from foreign oppression of their South Slavic brothers in the [[Balkan Wars]] and [[World War I]]. Serbian nationalists claim that in Communist historiography, Serbs were transformed into oppressors, the [[Chetniks]] of World War II branded as collaborationist as the [[Ustaše]], and the massacres of Serbs were downplayed.<ref name="Pavkovic2016">{{cite book|author=A. Pavkovic|title=The Fragmentation of Yugoslavia: Nationalism and War in the Balkans|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u3paCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA88|date=8 January 2016|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-0-230-28584-2|pages=88–}}</ref> In post-WW2 Yugoslavia, Serbian historians claimed that histories of individual peoples no longer existed after unification in contrast to Slovene and Croat historians who claimed otherwise.<ref name="KlemencicZagar99">{{cite book|last1=Klemenčič|first1=Matjaž|last2=Žagar|first2=Mitja|title=The former Yugoslavia's diverse peoples: A reference sourcebook|year=2004|publisher=Abc-Clio|isbn=978-1-57607-294-3|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ORSMBFwjAKcC&pg=PA99&dq=serbian+historians+World+War#v=onepage&q=serbian%20historians%20World%20War&f=false|page=99|ref=harv}}</ref> From the 1950s onward intellectual activities came less under state control and by the 1960s debates about the Second World reappeared culminating with more works in the 1980s.<ref name="Cox118">{{cite book|last=Cox|first=John K.|title=The history of Serbia|year=2002|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-31290-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=U765FGDfbPoC&pg=PA118&dq=Serbian+historians+debates#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20debates&f=false|page=118|ref=harv}}</ref>
=== Post communist Serbian historiography (1980s-present) === {{See also|Serbian nationalism|Yugoslav Wars|Propaganda during the Yugoslav Wars}}
Throughout the post war era, though Tito denounced nationalist sentiments in historiography, those trends continued with Croat and Serbian academics at times accusing each other of misrepresenting each other's histories, especially in relation to the Croat-Nazi alliance.<ref name="Kolander267">{{cite book|last=Kolander|first=Patricia|chapter= "Malevolent Partnership of Blatant Opportunism?" Croat-German Relations, 1919–1941|editor1-last=Bullivant|editor1-first=Keith|editor2-last=Giles|editor2-first=Geoffrey J.|editor3-last=Pape|editor3-first=Walter|title=Germany and Eastern Europe: Cultural identities and cultural differences|year=1999|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=978-90-420-0678-2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jXKk-gs-VNEC&pg=PA267&dq=Serbian+historiography+tito#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20tito&f=false|page=267|ref=harv}}</ref> Communist historiography was challenged in the 1980s and a rehabilitation of Serbian nationalism by Serbian historians began.<ref name="Brunnbauer364"/><ref name="Perica147">{{harvnb|Perica|2002|p=147.}}</ref> Historians and other members of the intelligentsia belonging to the [[Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts]] (SANU) and the [[Association of Writers of Serbia|Writers Association]] played a significant role in the explanation of the new historical narrative.<ref name="BieberGalijas117"/><ref name="Ramet19">{{harvnb|Ramet|2002|p=19.}}</ref><ref name="Ramet322">{{cite book|last=Ramet|first=Sabrina P.|title=The three Yugoslavias: State-building and legitimation, 1918–2005|year=2006|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=978-0-253-34656-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FTw3lEqi2-oC&pg=PA322&dq=Serbian+historiography+tito#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20tito&f=false|page=322|ref=harv}}</ref> The process of writing a "new Serbian history" paralleled alongside the emerging ethno-nationalist mobilisation of Serbs with the objective of reorganising the Yugoslav federation.<ref name="Perica147"/> Four factors and sources that influenced the "new history" include:<ref name="Perica147"/>
# Serbian ethno-nationalist ideology # Nationalism that originated from Church historiography and the Orthodox Church # Serbian émigré propaganda and myths # Genocide and Holocaust studies (due to Serbs identifying with Jews as crimes against Serbs were viewed alongside the Holocaust as being equivalent)
Using ideas and concepts from Holocaust historiography, Serbian historians alongside church leaders applied it to World War Two Yugoslavia and equated the Serbs with Jews and Croats with Nazi Germans.<ref name="Perica150">{{harvnb|Perica|2002|p=150.}}</ref> In relation to World War Two Serb casualties, during the Milošević era Serbian historians and the regime saw it as important to secure support from prominent Yugoslav Jewish individuals and organisations regarding the idea relating to a common Serbian-Jewish martyrdom.<ref name="Perica151">{{harvnb|Perica|2002|p=151.}}</ref> As such, a few Yugoslav Jews gave their assistance for the new Serbian historiography.<ref name="Perica151"/> In the 1980s, Serbian historians produced many works about the forced conversion during World War Two of Serbs to Catholicism in Ustaša Croatia.<ref name="Aleksov106">{{harvnb|Aleksov|2007|p=106.}}</ref> These debates between historians openly became nationalistic and also entered the wider media.<ref name="Brunnbauer364">{{cite book|last=Brunnbauer|first=Ulf|chapter=Historical Writing in the Balkans|editor1-last=Woolf|editor1-first=Daniel|editor2-last=Schneider|editor2-first=Axel|title=The Oxford History of Historical Writing: Volume 5: Historical Writing Since 1945|year=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-922599-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=eJ4SDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA364&dq=Serbian+historians+debates#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20debates&f=false|page=364|ref=harv}}</ref> Historians in Belgrade during the 1980s who had close government connections often went on television during the evenings to discuss invented or real details about the Ustaša genocide against Serbs during World War Two.<ref name="Stojanovic221"/> These discussions had the effect of being theoretical deductions that served as a precursor for the eventual ethno-demographic engineering that took place in Croatia.<ref name="Stojanovic221">{{harvnb|Stojanović|2011|p=221.}}</ref> During this time some well known Serbian historians such as [[Vasilije Krestić]] and [[Milorad Ekmečić]] were at the vanguard of the nationalist movement.<ref name="Armourxvii"/> In 1986, Vasilije Krestić alongside historian [[Radovan Samardžić]] were members of a commission that later drafted the ''[[SANU Memorandum|Memorandum of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts]]'' which referred to a "genocide" being committed against Serbs by Albanians and Croats in Yugoslavia.<ref name="Armourxvii">{{cite book|last=Armour|first=Ian D.|title=Apple of Discord: The" Hungarian Factor" in Austro-Serbian Relations, 1867–1881|year=2014|publisher=Purdue University Press|isbn=978-1-55753-683-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=kVncAwAAQBAJ&pg=PR16&dq=Serbian+historiography+tito#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20tito&f=false|pages=xvii|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Ramet1920">{{harvnb|Ramet|2002|pp=19–20.}}</ref>
During the 1980s and 1990s, the main focus of nationalist history was Kosovo.<ref name="Anscombe761"/> Serbian academics such as [[Dušan Bataković]] obtained generous support for publishing nationalist works which were translated into other languages and other Serbian historians [[Dimitrije Bogdanović]], Radovan Samardžić and [[Atanasije Urošević]] also produced similar works on Kosovo.<ref name="Anscombe761"/> Though some Serb historians did not promote nationalistic views, the practice of history within Serbia has been influenced by limitations placed upon it from state-sponsored nationalism.<ref name="Anscombe761"/> The focus of research for Serbian historians has been restricted to the Serbian experience of life under "the Turks" and only a few Serb historians can read Ottoman documents.<ref name="Anscombe761">{{harvnb|Anscombe|2006|p=761.}} "Even if some Serbian historians have not promoted a consciously nationalistic view, history as practised in Serbia has observed the constraints imposed by state-sponsored nationalism. As suggested in Part I, nation-building states in former Ottoman territories have used their influence over education, support for and dissemination of research, and the media to draw implicit, and sometimes explicit, boundaries for acceptable historical interpretation. Minor variations on the established narrative may be allowed, but even less overtly ideological historians remain chroniclers of the nation. As in most other post-Ottoman states, few historians in Serbia are able to read Ottoman texts: the focus of their research is confined to Serbs and Serbian lands under 'the Turks'. In the 1980s and 1990s, overtly nationalist Serbian scholars such as Dušan Bataković received the most generous support for the publication of their work. [2] The focus of much of such nationalist history was Kosovo. Footnote: [2] Bataković wrote a series of nationalist works on Kosovo, of which several (''The Kosovo Chronicles'' [Belgrade, 1992] and ''Kosovo, la spirals de la haine'' [Paris, 1993]) have been translated into other languages. Many similar works have not been translated: e.g., ''Kosovo i Metohija u srpskoj istoriji'', ed. R. Samardžic (Belgrade, 1989); D. Bogdanović, ''Knjiga o Kosovu'' (Belgrade, 1985); and A. Urošević, ''Etnički procesi na Kosovu tokom turske vladavine'' (Belgrade, 1987)."</ref> As such, Hapsburg documents have been used though Serbian historians sideline the corpus of local and important evidence based in Ottoman documents when compiling national history.<ref>{{harvnb|Anscombe|2006|p=771.}} "Malcolm, like the historians of Serbia and Yugoslavia who ignore his findings, overlooks the most valuable indigenous evidence. Unwillingness to consider Ottoman evidence when constructing national history is exemplified by the Serbian historians who commemorated the three-hundredth anniversary of the great migration by compiling a compendium of previously unpublished references to Serbs in contemporary documents, all of them Habsburg in origin and none of them Ottoman."</ref>
Works from Serbian historians and ethnographers that were academically obsolete and politically biased aiming to justify Serb expansionism were republished a century later with some works going for a second edition in the 1990s.<ref name="Aleksov96"/> These works were praised by Serb historians because they viewed them as almost being primary sources due to their archaic style and closeness to the described events and hence promoted their republishing during the 1990s.<ref name="Aleksov96">{{harvnb|Aleksov|2007|p=96.}} "The works of these historians and ethnographers, while scholarly obsolete and politically biased in their aim to justify Serbian expansionism, have nevertheless been revived almost a century later, and many of them went to a second edition in the 1990s. Serbian historians who praised them and advocated their reprinting in the 1990s treated them as if they were almost primary sources because of their archaic style and alleged proximity to events they described."</ref> Whereas the works and ideas of these 19th and early 20th century nationalistically oriented Serbian historians were expanded upon by writers on the Serbian literary scene during the 1990s.<ref name="HasimbegovicGavrilovic21">{{cite book|last1=Hašimbegović|first1=Elma|last2=Gavrilović|first2=Darko|chapter=Ethnogensis Myths|editor1-last=Bosković|editor1-first=Aleksandar|editor2-last=Dević|editor2-first=Ana|editor3-last=Hašimbegović|editor3-first=Elma|editor4-last=Ljubojević|editor4-first=Ana|editor5-last=Velikonja|editor5-first=Mitja|title=Political Myths in the Former Yugoslavia and Successor States|year=2011|publisher=Institute for Historical Justice and Reconciliation|isbn=978-90-8979-067-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FXC_BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA27&dq=bogomilism+Serbian+historiography#v=snippet&q=longevity&f=false|page=21|ref=harv}}</ref> When the wars broke out during the 1990s, most Serbian historians focused on suffering that Serbs had undergone in previous conflicts to emphasize past Serbian victimisation, ethnic cleansing of Serbs and sexual assaults against Serbian women.<ref name="Bokovoy183">{{cite book|last=Bokovoy|first=Melissa|chapter=Gender and Reframing of World War I in Serbia during the 1980s and 1990s|editor1-last=Regulska|editor1-first=Joanna|editor2-last=Smith|editor2-first=Bonnie G.|title=Women and gender in postwar Europe: From cold war to European Union|year=2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-45480-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=7PvIBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT310&dq=serbian+historians+World+War#v=onepage&q=serbian%20historians%20World%20War&f=false|page=183|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian historians defended the actions of the regime during the dissolution of Yugoslavia.<ref name="BieberGalijas117">{{harvnb|Bieber|Galijaš|2016|p=117}}</ref>
Few Serbian scholars have critically engaged with literature of Serbian historiography that is based heavily on myth.<ref>{{harvnb|Karić|2011|p=739.}} "In all fairness, it should be mentioned that there are a few Serbian scholars who have unmasked those works of Serbian historiography that relied heavily upon myth."</ref> Of those that have include historian [[Miodrag Popović]] who stated that Serbian history in the Ottoman Empire is separate from myths contained in Serbian folk poetry.<ref name="Karic739"/> Popović added that myths about the "Turkish yoke" and "slavery under the Turks" were a product of later times meant to mobilize Serbians during the nation-state building process which is why the myth contains so much anti-Islamic and anti-Turkish views.<ref name="Karic739">{{harvnb|Karić|2011|p=739.}}</ref> Serbian historiography in contemporary times still remains politically sensitive.<ref name="FeldmanTurda36">{{cite book|last1=Feldman|first1=Matthew|last2=Turda|first2=Marius|chapter='Clerical Fascism' in Interwar Europe: An introduction|editor1-last=Feldman|editor1-first=Matthew|editor2-last=Turda|editor2-first=Marius|editor3-last=Georgescu|editor3-first=Tudor|title=Clerical fascism in interwar Europe|year=2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-96899-3|url=https://books.google.com/?id=KcfhAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA36&dq=serbian+historiography+partisans#v=onepage&q=serbian%20historiography%20partisans&f=false|page=36|ref=harv}}</ref> The fall of the Milošević regime (2000) heralded divisions within the intelligentsia about coming to terms with the recent wartime past and moral responsibility in Serbia.<ref name="BieberGalijas120"/> Amongst liberal historians their efforts have been concentrated on refuting nationalist discourses prominent in media and public views and the failure of embracing modernity by Serbian society.<ref name="BieberGalijas120"/> Their views about the dissolution of Yugoslavia are based upon the wider polarization and mass debate contained in Serbian public debate regarding the past and as replies to nationalist discourses of historians affiliated with the nationalist-patriotic group.<ref name="BieberGalijas120">{{harvnb|Bieber|Galijaš|2016|p=120.}}</ref>
== Themes == Serbian historiography (19th century - present) has through its historians developed various histriographical positions, views and conclusions on subjects and topics that relates to the study of Serbian history and the Serb people. Of those are:
=== Medieval and pre-independence periods ===
In Serbian historiography there is a divergence of positions regarding [[Byzantine culture|Byzantine cultural]] influence on Serbia with some Serbian historians supporting the view that there was and others seeing it as being minimal.<ref name="Mishkova200">{{cite book|last=Mishkova|first=Diana|chapter=The afterlife of a Commonwealth: Narratives of Byzantium in the National Historiographies of Greece, Bulgaria, Serbia and Romania|editor1-last=Daskalov|editor1-first=Roumen|editor2-last=Vezenkov|editor2-first=Alexander |title=Entangled Histories of the Balkans-Volume Three: Shared Pasts, Disputed Legacies|year=2015|publisher=Brill|isbn=978-90-04-29036-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=WDRzBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA200&dq=Serb+historians+controversy#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historians%20controversy&f=false|page=200|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian historians have contended that [[Vlachs]] in [[Dalmatia]] during the early [[Middle Ages]] were thoroughly Slavonicised and hence to be really Serbs.<ref name="Judah11">{{cite book|last=Judah|first=Tim|title=The Serbs: History, myth, and the destruction of Yugoslavia|year=2000|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-08507-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=B4YbP0fPcMYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Serbian+historians+Islam#v=snippet&q=Serbian%20historians%20vlachs%20dalmatia&f=false|page=11|ref=harv}}</ref> The rivalry between [[Branimir of Croatia|Prince Branimir]] (ruled 879–887) who chose (Catholic) Rome over (Orthodox) Constantinople and Duke Sedeslav (ruled 878–879) who favoured Constantinople ended in execution of the latter by the former.<ref name="Perica65"/> In Serbian church historiography, Sedeslav is viewed as a martyr of the Orthodox church and Branimir's rise to power is interpreted as disastrous that divided two Slavic peoples who both until that time leaned toward the Orthodox church.<ref name="Perica65"/> [[Demetrius Zvonimir of Croatia|King Zvonimir]] (ruled 1075–1089) a figure who consolidated Catholicism and rejected Orthodoxy in Croatia is viewed by Serbian Church historians as an enemy of the Orthodox Christian religion.<ref name="Perica65">{{harvnb|Perica|2002|p=65.}}</ref> Serbian historians contend that the medieval [[Bosnian Church]] was part of the Orthodox church and not heretical.<ref name="Bringa15">{{cite book|last=Bringa|first=Tone|title=Being Muslim the Bosnian way: Identity and community in a central Bosnian village|year=1995|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-0-691-00175-3|url=https://books.google.com/?id=iqtVESaJUgkC&pg=PA15&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islamization#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islamization&f=false|page=15|ref=harv}}</ref>
Serbian historiography emphasizes an Orthodox Serbian origin for the [[Bosniaks]] who are interpreted as relinquishing ties to that ethno-religious heritage after converting to Islam and later denying it by refusing to accept a Serbian identity.<ref name="Bieber2006">{{cite book|last=Bieber|first=Florian|title=Post-War Bosnia: Ethnicity, Inequality and Public Sector Governance|url=https://books.google.com/?id=7R9_DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA5&dq=Serbian+historiography+Bosniaks#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Bosniaks&f=false|year=2006|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-50137-9|page=5|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Mekic17">{{cite book|last=Mekić|first=Sejad|title=A Muslim Reformist in Communist Yugoslavia: The Life and Thought of Husein Đozo|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ECqTDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA17&dq=Serbian+historiography+Bosniac#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Bosniac&f=false|year=2016|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-230-50137-9|page=17|ref=harv}}</ref> While the battle of Kosovo (1389) against Muslim Ottoman forces has been taken out of its context within Serbian historiography.<ref name="Keles65"/> That event has been utilized by placing it within the wider Serbian political objective of vilifying Bosnian Muslims by associating their conversion to Islam with the identity of the Ottoman invader.<ref name="Keles65">{{cite book|last=Keles|first=Fethi|chapter=Bridging the macro with the micro in conflict analysis: Structural simplification as a heuristic device|editor1-last=Fleishman|editor1-first=Rachel|editor2-last=O'Leary|editor2-first=Rosemary|editor3-last=Gerard|editor3-first=Catherine|title=Pushing the Boundaries: New Frontiers in Conflict Resolution and Collaboration|year=2008|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing|isbn=978-1-84855-291-3|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qBN27442rkYC&pg=PA65&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islam&f=false|page=65|ref=harv}}</ref> Bosnian Muslims within the bulk of Serbian nationalist historiography are presented as the descendants of the mentally ill, lazy, slaves, greedy landlords, prisoners, thieves, outcasts or as Serbs who confused and defeated chose to follow their enemies religion.<ref name="Alibasic431">{{cite book|last=Alibašić|first=Ahmet|chapter=Bosnia and Herzegovina|editor1-last=Cesari|editor1-first=Jocelyne|title=The Oxford Handbook of European Islam|year=2014|location=Oxford|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-102640-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=NW7DBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA431&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islamization#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islamization&f=false|page=431|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian historiography mythologized the emergence of Islam within the Balkans as the outcome of coercion and the [[Devshirme|devşirme]] system instead of it being a genuine and complex phenomenon.<ref name="Ingrao110">{{cite book|last=Ingrao|first=Charles W.|title=Confronting the Yugoslav Controversies: A Scholars' Initiative|url=https://books.google.com/?id=t0nYdgFrdG8C&pg=PA110&dq=Serbian+historiography+Bosniaks#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Bosniaks&f=false|year=2009|publisher=Purdue University Press|isbn=978-1-55753-533-7|page=110|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Aleksov100">{{harvnb|Aleksov|2007|p=100.}}</ref>
Serbian history often emphasizes that the [[Serbian Patriarchate of Peć|Patriarchate of Peć]] was reestablished (1557) by [[Sokollu Mehmed Pasha]], a grand vizier from Bosnia who by origin was of Orthodox Christian heritage and thus claimed as a Serb in Serbian history, while a relative of his became the first patriarch.<ref>{{harvnb|Anscombe|2006|p=765.}} "Serbian history makes much of the fact that the re-establishment of the patriarchate of Peć in 1557 was attributable to Sokollu Mehmed Pasha, by origin an Orthodox Christian from Bosnia (and thus claimed as a member of the nation in Serbian history), and grand vizier late in the reign of Sultan Suleyman I ('The Magnificent') and early in that of his successor, Selim II. One of Mehmed's relatives became the first patriarch."</ref> In some Serbian historiography, the Orthodox clergy is ascribed as having played a leading military and ideological role during the [[First Serbian Uprising]] (1804–1813).<ref name="Lampe147">{{cite book|last=Lampe|first=John R.|chapter=Nationalism in Former Yugoslavia|editor1-last=Latawski|editor1-first=Paul|title=Contemporary Nationalism in East Central Europe|year=1995|publisher=St Martin's Press|isbn=978-1-349-23809-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Kgq_DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA147&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=147|ref=harv}}</ref> Adopting mainly the perspective of Eastern European traditions, Serbian historiography views the national struggle as having been attained through liberation from what has been referred to as "five centuries of" the "Turkish yoke".<ref name="Omerika154">{{cite book|last=Omerika|first=Armina|chapter=Competing national Orientalisms: The cases of Belgrade and Sarajevo|editor1-last=Kemper|editor1-first=Michael|editor2-last=Kalinovsky|editor2-first=Artemy M.|title=Reassessing Orientalism: Interlocking Orientologies During the Cold War|year=2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-63670-0|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sr2gBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA154&dq=Serbian+historiography+Bosniaks#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Bosniaks&f=false|page=154|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Spasic84">{{cite book|last=Spasić|first=Ivana|chapter=The trauma of Kosovo in Serbian national narratives|editor1-last=Eyerman|editor1-first=Ronald|editor2-last=Alexander|editor2-first=Jeffrey C.|editor3-last=Breese|editor3-first=Elizabeth Butler|title=Narrating trauma: on the impact of collective suffering|year=2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-25569-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=XNXOCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA84&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islam&f=false|page=84|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian historiography views the Serbs as being at the vanguard of protecting Balkan Christians.<ref name="Gilberg7"/> The ''[[Mountain Wreath]]'', a 19th-century poem written by [[Petar II Petrović-Njegoš|Petar Petrović Njegoš]] containing a narrative about Slavic Muslims refusing to revert to Christianity followed up with their massacre is viewed within Serbian historiography as part of the ideology of national liberation from Ottoman rule.<ref name="Karpat179">{{cite book|last=Karpat|first=Kemal H.|title=The politicization of Islam: Reconstructing identity, state, faith, and community in the late Ottoman state|year=2001|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-513618-0|url=https://books.google.com/?id=PvVlS3ljx20C&pg=PA179&dq=Serbian+historians+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Islam&f=false|page=179|ref=harv}}</ref> Critical Serbian historiography views the event to be mythical as Montenegrin tribal customs did not allow for fellow clan members to be killed.<ref name="Vujacic135">{{cite book|last=Vujačić|first=Veljko|title=Nationalism, Myth, and the State in Russia and Serbia|year=2015|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-07408-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=E7DGBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA134&dq=Serbian+historians+Islam#v=onepage&q=incessant%20struggle&f=false|page=135|ref=harv}}</ref>
=== Independence, World War One and Interwar Yugoslavia ===
From the first Serbian Uprising (1804) onward, Serb historians have viewed the Balkans as a region of perpetual ethnic conflicts of whom Balkan peoples have been anti-Serb for centuries.<ref name="Karic738">{{harvnb|Karić|2011|p=738.}}</ref> Within Serbian historiography, "minority" groups have been portrayed as unreliable with "natural" tendencies for rebellion, treachery and deceit.<ref name="Blumi190">{{cite book|last=Blumi|first=Isa|title=Foundations of Modernity: Human Agency and the Imperial State|year=2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-88464-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Q7usAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT245&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islam&f=false|page=190|ref=harv}}</ref> Within Serbian historiography references to Muslim treachery and Albanian irredentism were made that coincided with new campaigns to expel people from Macedonia and Kosovo to Turkey.<ref name="Blumi230">{{cite book|last=Blumi|first=Isa|title=Ottoman refugees, 1878–1939: Migration in a Post-Imperial World|year=2013|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-1-4725-1538-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=yTOaAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT304&dq=serbian+historiography+balkan+wars#v=onepage&q=serbian%20historiography%20balkan%20wars&f=false|page=230|ref=harv}}</ref>
Serbian historiography holds the view that Russians and Serbs have a special relationship expressed through [[Slavophilism]] and [[pan-Slavism]] and that both peoples are part of a larger Slavic "brotherhood".<ref name="Gilberg7"/> In the early 20th century, Serbian historiography in geography textbooks had a tendency to serving the political goal of Greater Serbia by viewing the bulk of Balkan Slavic lands as inhabited by Serbs, until the Yugoslav idea gradually shifted those views.<ref name="Segesten48">{{cite book|last=Segesten|first=Anamaria Dutceac|title=Myth, identity, and conflict: A comparative analysis of Romanian and Serbian textbooks|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Yyg0XvRlfuIC&pg=PA48&dq=Serbian+historiography+Bosniaks#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Bosniaks&f=false|year=2011|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=978-1-109-19838-6|page=48|ref=harv}}</ref> Patriotic Serbian historiography portrays the Serbs during the Balkan Wars (1912–1913) and World War One (1914–1918) as liberating fellow South Slavs from foreign oppressors.<ref name="Pavkovic88">{{cite book|last=Pavković|first=Aleksandar|title=The fragmentation of Yugoslavia: Nationalism and war in the Balkans|url=https://books.google.com/?id=u3paCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA88&dq=Serb+historiography+kosovo#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historiography%20kosovo&f=false|year=2000|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-28584-2|page=88|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian historians have viewed the Balkan wars (1912–1913) as mainly a Serbian event of state expansion.<ref name="Troch91">{{cite book|last=Troch|first=Pieter|title=Nationalism and Yugoslavia: Education, Yugoslavism and the Balkans before World War II|year=2015|publisher=Pieter Troch|isbn=978-0-85773-768-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dgLaCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT108&dq=Serbian+historians+Balkan+wars#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Balkan%20wars&f=false|page=91|ref=harv}}</ref> Regarding the post-World War One unification of Montenegro with Serbia, Serbian alongside Montenegrin historians attempted to critically analyze the events though were hampered by political concerns and ideological bias of the Yugoslav era.<ref name="Pavlovic13"/> Only in recent times have a few Serbian and Montenegrin historians with less ideological baggage attempted to engage with the events.<ref name="Pavlovic13">{{cite book|last=Pavlović|first=Srdja|title=Balkan Anschluss: The annexation of Montenegro and the creation of the common South Slavic state|url=https://books.google.com/?id=4LPfuwer21EC&pg=PA13&dq=Serbian+historians+historiography#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20historiography&f=false|year=2008|publisher=Purdue University Press|isbn=978-1-55753-465-1|page=13|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian historians assert that during the period of the Balkan Wars, a [[Macedonians (ethnic group)|Macedonian nation]] was nonexistent and that local Slavs were either Serbian or [[Bulgarians|Bulgarian]].<ref name="Despot243">{{cite book|last=Despot|first=Igor|title=The Balkan Wars in the Eyes of the Warring Parties: Perceptions and Interpretations|year=2012|publisher=iUniverse|isbn=978-1-4759-4703-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZIbtG7w_rSUC&pg=PA243&dq=Serbian+historians+historiography#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20historiography&f=false|page=243|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Detrez125">{{cite book|last=Detrez|first=Raymond|chapter=The right to self determination and Secession in Yugoslavia: A Hornets Nest of Inconsistencies|editor1-last=Coppieters|editor1-first=Bruno|editor2-last=Sakwa|editor2-first=Richard |title=Contextualizing secession: Normative studies in comparative perspective|year=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-925871-0|url=https://books.google.com/?id=seUTDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA125&dq=serb+historiography+albanian+independence#v=onepage&q=serb%20historiography%20albanian%20independence&f=false|page=125|ref=harv}}</ref>
The assassin [[Gavrilo Princip]] who in Sarajevo (1914) [[Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria|killed Archduke Franz Ferdinand]] is viewed by Serbian historians as a Serbian hero.<ref name="Stojanovic230">{{harvnb|Stojanović|2011|p=230.}}</ref> A majority of Serbian historians view [[Austria-Hungary]] and [[German Empire|Germany]] ([[Central Powers]]) as instigating the [[First World War]] while the actions of ''[[Mlada Bosna]]'' are presented as being autonomous and not dependent on Serbian government circles.<ref name="Petrovskaya37"/> The role of the [[Russian Empire]] and the position it took on the eve of war is portrayed favorably within Serbian historiography.<ref name="Petrovskaya37">{{cite book|last=Petrovskaya|first=Oksana|chapter=The origins of the First World War in the modern historiography of Post Communist Eastern Europe|editor1-last=Biagini|editor1-first=Antonello|editor2-last=Motta|editor2-first=Giovanna|title=The First World War: Analysis and Interpretation, Volume 1|year=2015|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|isbn=978-1-4438-8186-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=r4HWCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA37&dq=Serbian+historians+debates#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20debates&f=false|page=37|ref=harv}}</ref>
Some Serbian historians are of the view that the ideology of [[Yugoslavism]] and the creation of the [[Subdivisions of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia|banovinas]] diminished Serbian identity.<ref name="Nielsen107"/> Others Serbian historians have suggested the opposite in that the banovinas strengthened Yugoslavia by making Serbs the dominant group within 6 of them.<ref name="Nielsen107">{{cite book|last=Nielsen|first=Christian Axboe|title=Making Yugoslavs: Identity in King Aleksandar's Yugoslavia|year=2014|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-1-4426-2750-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ksAeBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA107&dq=Serb+historiography+Yugoslavism#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historiography%20Yugoslavism&f=false|page=107|ref=harv}}</ref> The actions of Serbs within interwar Yugoslavia are portrayed in nationalist Serbian historiography as defensive and to safeguard the state from Croatian secessionism that is blamed for state's unstable interwar parliamentary system.<ref name="Biondich45">{{cite book|last=Biondich|first=Mark|chapter=The historical legacy: The evolution of interwar Yugoslav Politics, 1918–1941|editor1-last=Cohen|editor1-first=Lenard J.|editor2-last=Dragović-Soso|editor2-first=Jasna|title=State collapse in South-Eastern Europe: New perspectives on Yugoslavia's disintegration|year=2008|publisher=Purdue University Press|isbn=978-1-55753-460-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=aGy3dO_aDisC&pg=PA45&dq=Serbian+historiography+tito#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20tito&f=false|page=45|ref=harv}}</ref>
=== World War Two === [[Chetniks]] along with the Ustaša were vilified by Tito era historiography within Yugoslavia.<ref name="Ramet129"/> In the 1980s, Serbian historians initiated the process of reexamining the narrative of how World War Two was told in Yugoslavia which was accompanied by the rehabilitation of Chetnik leader [[Draža Mihailović]].<ref name="EmmertIngrao42">{{cite book|last=Emmert|first=Thomas|last2=Ingrao|first2=Charles|title=Conflict in Southeastern Europe at the End of the Twentieth Century: A" Scholars' Initiative" Assesses Some of the Controversies|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gUqOAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA42&dq=Serbian+historians+controversy#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20controversy&f=false|year=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-97016-3|page=42|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Drapac282">{{cite book|last=Drapac|first=Vesna|chapter=Catholic resistance and collaboration in the Second World War: From Master Narrative to Practical Application|editor1-last=Rutar|editor1-first=Sabine|editor2-last=|editor2-first=|title=Beyond the Balkans: Towards an Inclusive History of Southeastern Europe|year=2014|publisher=LIT Verlag|isbn=978-3-643-10658-2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=lISdAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA282&dq=Serbian+historians+debates#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20debates&f=false|page=282|ref=harv}}</ref> Monographs relating to Mihailović and the Chetnik movement were produced by some younger historians who were ideologically close to it toward the end of the 1990s.<ref name="Stojanovic249">{{cite book|last=Stojanović|first=Dubravka|chapter=|editor1-last=Ramet|editor1-first=Sabrina|editor2-last=Listhaug|editor2-first=Ole|title=Serbia and the Serbs in World War Two|year=2011|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-0-230-34781-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gkiEDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA111&dq=Serbian+historians+debates#v=onepage&q=The%20knife&f=false|page=249|ref=harv}}</ref> Being preoccupied with the era, Serbian historians have looked to vindicate Chetnik history by portraying Chetniks as righteous freedom fighters battling the Nazis while removing from history books the ambiguous alliances with the Italians and Germans.<ref name="MacDonald138">{{cite book|last=MacDonald|first=David Bruce|title=Balkan Holocausts?: Serbian and Croatian victim centred propaganda and the war in Yugoslavia|url=https://books.google.com/?id=kBjrJyen4FEC&pg=PA138&dq=Serbian+historians+controversy#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20controversy&f=false|year=2003|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=978-0-7190-6467-8|page=138|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Ramet129">{{cite book|last=Ramet|first=Sabrina P.|title=Serbia since 1989: Politics and Society under Milopevic and After|year=2005|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-80207-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dhITCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA129&dq=Serbian+historiography+tito#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20tito&f=false|page=129|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Subotic201">{{cite book|last=Subotic|first=Jelena|chapter=The Mythologizing of Communist Violence|editor1-last=Stan|editor1-first=Lavinia|editor2-last=Nedelsky|editor2-first=Nadya|title=Post-communist Transitional Justice: Lessons from Twenty-five Years of Experience|year=2015|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-06556-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=twFEBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA201&dq=serbian+historiography+partisans#v=onepage&q=serbian%20historiography%20partisans&f=false|page=201|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Finney353">{{cite book|last=Finney|first=Patrick|chapter=Land of Ghosts: Memories of War in the Balkans|editor1-last=Buckley|editor1-first=John|editor2-last=Kassimeris|editor2-first=George|title=The Ashgate research companion to modern warfare|year=2010|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-4094-9953-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qUjCI13U5VUC&pg=PA353&dq=Serbian+historians+debates#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20debates&f=false|page=353|ref=harv}}</ref> Whereas the crimes committed by Chetniks against Croats and Muslims in Serbian historiography are overall "cloaked in silence".<ref name="Becirevic46"/> During the Milošević era, Serbian history was falsified to obscure the role Serbian collaborators [[Milan Nedić]] and [[Dimitrije Ljotić]] played in cleansing Serbia's Jewish community, killing them in the country or deporting them to Eastern European concentration camps.<ref name="Perica151">{{harvnb|Perica|2002|p=151.}}</ref>
The topic of World War Two Serbian population casualties has been strongly debated since the conclusion of World War Two.<ref name="Tomasevich718"/><ref name="Watson177"/> Within Serbian historiography, documenting Nazi and Ustaša crimes against the Roma, Jews and Serbs was undertaken as a priority.<ref name="Becirevic46">{{harvnb|Bećirević|2014|p=46.}}</ref> For Serbian historians, the Independent State of Croatia was responsible for the death of hundreds of thousands of Serbs throughout rural areas and in concentration camps such as [[Jasenovac concentration camp|Jasenovac]].<ref name="Tomasevich718">{{cite book|last=Tomasevich|first=Jozo|title=War and Revolution in Yugoslavia: 1941–1945|url=https://books.google.com/?id=fqUSGevFe5MC&pg=PA718&dq=Serb+historians+controversy#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historians%20controversy&f=false|year=2001|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-7924-1|page=718|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Watson177">{{cite book|last=Watson|first=Rubie S.|title= Memory, History and Opposition: Under State Socialism|url=https://books.google.com/?id=m6h-5l2anLgC&pg=PA177&dq=Serbian+historians+historiography#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20historiography&f=false|year=1999|publisher=James Currey Publishers|isbn=978-0-85255-902-4|page=177|ref=harv}}</ref> During the 1980s and 1990s, the issue of World War Two civilian casualties were contested and subject to manipulation between Croats and Serbs.<ref name="Cox118"/><ref name="LukicLynch35">{{cite book|last1=Lukic|first1=Reneo|last2=Lynch|first2=Allen|title=Europe from the Balkans to the Urals: The disintegration of Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union|year=1996|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-829200-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=WPhhLfp8huIC&pg=PA35&dq=serbian+historians+World+War#v=onepage&q=serbian%20historians%20World%20War&f=false|page=35|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Stone109"/> Serbian historians alongside politicians exaggerated often the figures of those killed at Jasenovac to spread fear among the wider Serbian populace during the breakup of Yugoslavia.<ref name="Stone109">{{cite book|last=Stone|first=Dan|chapter=Genocide and Memory|editor1-last=Bloxham|editor1-first=Donald|editor2-last=Moses|editor2-first=A. Dirk|title=The Oxford handbook of Genocide Studies|year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-161361-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=xCHMFHQRNtYC&pg=PP174&dq=serbian+historians+World+War#v=onepage&q=serbian%20historians%20World%20War&f=false|page=109|ref=harv}}</ref>
Historiography within Tito's Yugoslavia had presented the Ustaša Independent State of Croatia (NDH) as an imposition of Nazi invaders and a deviation within the history of the Croats.<ref name="Perica147"/> By the middle of the 1980s this portrayal was challenged by Serbian historians.<ref name="Perica147"/> They contended that the Independent State of Croatia was a well organised entity that inflicted genocide upon the Serbs that had been in the making for several centuries in Croatia.<ref name="Perica147"/> During the 1980s, the [[Holy See|Vatican]] became a focus for Serbian historiography.<ref name="Perica181"/> The popes were depicted as anti-Serbian, as being intrinsic to the demise of interwar Yugoslavia and taking part in the genocide against Serbians within the pro-Axis [[Independent State of Croatia]].<ref name="Perica181"/> The new Serbian historiography of the 1980s of which secular and church historians contributed highlighted the role that religion played in being as the main source of Serbian-Croatian enmities.<ref name="Perica147"/> The Catholic Church was portrayed as the main carrier of hatred that inspired the idea of genocide against the Serbs during World War Two.<ref name="Perica147">{{harvnb|Perica|2002|p=147.}}</ref> In the works of Serbian historians, the Vatican is linked to a recurring Croatian plot to destroy Serbia.<ref name="Cox118">{{cite book|last=Cox|first=John K.|title=The history of Serbia|year=2002|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-31290-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=U765FGDfbPoC&pg=PA118&dq=Serbian+historians+debates#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20debates&f=false|page=118|ref=harv}}</ref> Using analogies from the Vatican's historic role in the Balkans, Serbian historians asserted that the Vatican did not understand the implications of the Muslim-Albanian awakening in Kosovo and other parts of Yugoslavia.<ref name="Perica181">{{cite book|last=Perica|first=Vjekoslav|chapter=The politics of ambivalence: Europeanization and the Serbian Orthodox Church|editor1-last=Byrnes|editor1-first=Timothy A.|editor2-last=Katzenstein|editor2-first=Peter J.|title=Religion in an expanding Europe|year=2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-45094-2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gKkA3GdCM78C&pg=PA181&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islam&f=false|page=181|ref=harv}}</ref>
Among Serbian historians focusing on World War Two, they interpret the Albanian [[Balli Kombëtar]] movement as either "anti-Yugoslav" or "counter revolutionary".<ref name="Ramet32"/> While the Bujan Conference (1943) is viewed as contravening the anti-fascist struggle due to Albanian communists insisting on the allocation of Kosovo to Albania at the war's conclusion.<ref name="Ramet32">{{cite book|last=Ramet|first=Sabrina P.|chapter=|editor1-last=Buckley|editor1-first=Mary|editor2-last=Cummings|editor2-first=Sally|title=Kosovo: Perceptions of war and its aftermath|year=2001|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-0-8264-5669-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qeOEysQTpcoC&pg=PA32&dq=Serbian+historiography+balli+Komb%C3%ABtar#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20balli%20Komb%C3%ABtar&f=false|page=32|ref=harv}}</ref> Though Tito was against such unification, in the 1980s Serbian historians held the Bujan meeting against him.<ref name="Lampe228">{{cite book|last=Lampe|first=John R.|title=Yugoslavia as history: Twice there was a country|year=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-77401-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=AZ1x7gvwx_8C&pg=PA228&dq=Serbian+historiography+balli+Komb%C3%ABtar#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20balli%20Komb%C3%ABtar&f=false|page=228|ref=harv}}</ref> Within Yugoslavia until the 1990s, Serbian historiography celebrated the aid given to Albania by Yugoslavia after the Second World War.<ref name="Ceku42">{{cite book|last=Çeku|first=Ethem|title=Kosovo and Diplomacy since World War II: Yugoslavia, Albania and the Path to Kosovan Independence|year=2015|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-0-85773-953-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=YoyTCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT45&dq=Serbian+historiography+balli#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20balli&f=false|page=42|ref=harv}}</ref>
=== Kosovo ===
In Serbian historiography [[Prince Lazar]], a figure who assembled Serb forces at the battle of Kosovo to fight the Ottomans is portrayed as a blessed martyr.<ref name="Galbreath83">{{cite book|last=Galbreath|first=David J.|title=The organization for security and co-operation in Europe (OSCE)|year=2007|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-13353-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=v7d8AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA83&dq=Serb+historiography+kosovo#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historiography%20kosovo&f=false|page=83|ref=harv}}</ref> Amidst the Kosovo Battle anniversary of the late 1980s, two Serbian historians independently concluded after critical historiographical analysis that [[Vuk Branković]] during the Kosovo battle was not a traitor and this finding is considered an important milestone for Serbian historiography.<ref name="Popov205">{{cite book|last=Popov|first=Nebojša|title=The road to war in Serbia: Trauma and catharsis|year=2000|publisher=Central European University Press|isbn=978-963-9116-56-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=GkBmdCwHuDsC&pg=PA205&dq=Serb+historiography+kosovo#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historiography%20kosovo&f=false|page=205|ref=harv}}</ref> Of the Serbian historians who have accepted Serbian mythology, the battle of Kosovo is viewed as the main battle overriding all other battles and for some of them it is viewed as a historical idea assisting the nation to connect with a real historical past.<ref>{{harvnb|Karić|2011|p=739.}} "While for the Ottoman the battle of Kosovo was one among many battles, for Serbian historians who accepted Serbian mythology, this battle is the key battle, the battle of all battles."</ref><ref name="Daskalovski13">{{cite book|last=Daskalovski|first=Židas|chapter=Claims to Kosovo: Nationalism and Self-determination|editor1-last=Bieber|editor1-first=Florian|editor2-last=Daskalovski|editor2-first=Židas|title=Understanding the war in Kosovo|year=2003|publisher=Psychology Press|url=https://books.google.com/?id=6OiQAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA13&dq=Serbian+historians+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Islam&f=false|isbn=978-0-7146-5391-4|page=13|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Fleming87">{{cite book|last=Fleming|first=Colin M.|title=Clausewitz's Timeless Trinity: A Framework For Modern War|year=2016|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-16522-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rlo3DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA87&dq=Serb+historiography+kosovo#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historiography%20kosovo&f=false|page=87|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian historians until the late 1940s were still portraying the Kosovo battle as a "victory" of the Serbs over the Ottoman Turks.<ref name="Ramet173">{{cite book|last=Ramet|first=Sabrina P.|title=Eastern Europe: Politics, culture, and society since 1939|year=1998|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=978-0-253-21256-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=eWmDAd6vr5sC&pg=PA173&dq=Serbian+historians+Albanian#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Albanian&f=false|page=173|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian historiography contends that from the Battle of Kosovo (1389) onward, Serbians have undergone centuries of oppression by the Muslim-Ottoman Empire and they have fought to restore their medieval [[Serbian empire]].<ref name="Duijzings89"/><ref name="Gort345">{{cite book|last=Gort|first=Jerald D.|last2=Jansen|first2=Henry|last3=Vroom|first3=Hendrik M.|title=Religion, conflict and reconciliation: Multifaith ideals and realities|year=2002|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=978-90-420-1166-3|url=https://books.google.com/?id=VJ0UxLFlsiAC&pg=PA345&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islam&f=false|page=345|ref=harv}}</ref> The [[Kosovo Myth|Kosovo myth]] still influences Serbian historiography as Serbian martyrdom and suffering alongside conflict and incompatibility between Christianity and Islam are emphasized.<ref name="Duijzings89"/> The battle of Kosovo is for Serbian historiography the historical event that legitimizes the claim of the Serbian character of Kosovo.<ref name="Hjarpe116">{{cite book|last=Hjärpe|first=Jan|chapter=Historiography and Islamic Vocabulary in War and Peace: A Memento for conflict resolution in the Muslim World|editor1-last=Fry|editor1-first=Douglas P.|editor2-last=Björkqvist|editor2-first=Kaj |title=Cultural variation in conflict resolution: Alternatives to violence|year=2013|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-135-80883-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=cSdKE6wLYQMC&pg=PT115&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islam&f=false|page=116|ref=harv}}</ref>
[[File:Seoba Srba 1690. Franc Juza.jpg|thumb|250px|Serbs crossing the river for Austrian territory, 1690.]] Some Serbian historians contend that a document issued on 6 April 1690 by the Austrian emperor referred to an "invitation" for Serbs to resettle in Hungary.<ref name="Ramet206">{{cite book|last=Ramet|first=Sabrina P.|title=Thinking about Yugoslavia: Scholarly debates about the Yugoslav breakup and the wars in Bosnia and Kosovo|year=2005|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-61690-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jSc6lOY1M2YC&pg=PA206&dq=Serb+historiography+great+migration#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historiography%20great%20migration&f=false|page=206|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian settlement on the Pannonian plain is viewed within Serbian historiography as the outcome of a cataclysmic exodus from Kosovo that occurred in 1690 called the ''[[Great Migrations of the Serbs|Great Migration (Velika Seoba)]]'' after Kosovan Serbs rebelled and joined incoming Hapsburg forces battling the Ottomans.<ref name="Anzulovic70">{{cite book|last=Anzulovic|first=Branimir|title=Heavenly Serbia: From myth to genocide|year=1999|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=978-0-8147-0671-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=CWMVCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA70&dq=Serb+historiography+great+migration#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historiography%20great%20migration&f=false|page=70|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Anscombe769770"/> Serbian historians regard the migration as being undertaken on a huge scale.<ref name="Malcolm140">{{cite book|last=Malcolm|first=Noel|title=Kosovo: A short history|year=1998|location=London|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-333-66612-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=GGQ_AQAAIAAJ&q=Serbian+historians+great+migration&dq=Serbian+historians+great+migration|page=140|ref=harv}}</ref>
Serbian historians have often dealt with Albanian history in an narrowly nationalist approach.<ref name="Magas47">{{cite book|last=Magaš|first=Branka|title=The destruction of Yugoslavia: Tracking the break-up 1980–92|year=1993|publisher=Verso|isbn=978-0-86091-593-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=d5np99Vgc0YC&pg=PA47&dq=Serbian+historians+Albanian#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Albanian&f=false|page=47|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian historians dispute the argument that Albanians are the descendants of ancient [[Illyrians]] and being established in the region prior to the Slavs, while contending that the presence of Albanians in the Balkans starts from the 11th century.<ref name="Muhic81">{{cite book|last=Muhić|first=Maja|chapter=The paradox of the Solution: The impact of the Kosovo question on Macedonia|editor1-last=Hudson|editor1-first=Robert|editor2-last=Bowman|editor2-first=Glenn|title=After Yugoslavia: Identities and politics within the successor states|year=2011|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-20131-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wkQ3I6GyClEC&pg=PA81&dq=Serbian+historiography+Bosniaks#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Bosniaks&f=false|page=81|ref=harv}}</ref> The majority of contemporary Serbian historiography portrays a situation of conflictual relations between Serbians and Albanians after they converted to Islam.<ref name="Duijzings89">{{cite book|last=Duijzings|first=Gerlachlus|title=Religion and the politics of identity in Kosovo|year=2000|publisher=Hurst & Company|isbn=978-1-85065-431-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=aJRYkzl5YC4C&pg=PA9&dq=Serbian+historiography+Islam#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Islam&f=false|pages=8–9|ref=harv}}</ref> Scholarship on Kosovo has also encompassed Ottoman provincial surveys that has revealed the 15th century ethnic composition of some Kosovo settlements, however like their Albanian counterparts, Serbian historians using these records have made much of them while proving little.<ref>{{harvnb|Anscombe|2006|p=785.}} "While the ethnic roots of some settlements can be determined from the Ottoman records, Serbian and Albanian historians have at times read too much into them in their running dispute over the ethnic history of early Ottoman Kosovo. Their attempts to use early Ottoman provincial surveys (tahrir defterleri) to gauge the ethnic make-up of the population in the fifteenth century have proved little."</ref>
Serbian historiography does not support the Albanian argument that the progenitors of Kosovan Albanians were native to Kosovo.<ref name="Banac294295"/> Instead within Serbian historiography the presence of Kosovan Albanians and their eventual predominance in the region has been attributed by (nationalist) Serbian historians<ref name="Janssens50"/> to a number of causes. Of those either the arrival and northward spread of Albanians from Albania after the Ottoman conquest, the [[Great Turkish War|Austro-Ottoman war]] that led to the northward migration of Serbs in 1690 with replacement by Albanians and or the assimilation of local Serbians into Albanians.<ref name="Banac294295">{{cite book|last=Banac|first=Ivo|title=The national question in Yugoslavia: Origins, history, politics|year=1988|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0-8014-9493-2|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=KfqbujXqQBkC&q=redskins#v=snippet&q=redskins&f=false|pages=294–295|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Winnifrith8">{{cite book|last=Winnifrith|first=Tom|title=Perspectives on Albania|year=1992|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-349-22050-2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=BDywCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA8&dq=Serbian+historians+Albanian#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Albanian&f=false|page=8|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="PavlakovicRamet79">{{cite book|last1=Pavlakovic|first1=Vjeran|last2=Ramet|first2=Sabrina Petra|chapter= Albanian and Serb rivalry in Kosovo: Realist and universalist perspectives on sovereignty|editor1-last=Bahcheli|editor1-first=Tozun|editor2-last=Bartmann|editor2-first=Barry|editor3-last=Srebrnik|editor3-first=Henry|title=De facto states: The quest for sovereignty|year=2004|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-77121-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Gk2QAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA79&dq=Serbian+historians+Albanian#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Albanian&f=false|page=79|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Bideleux516">{{cite book|last1=Bideleux|first1=Robert|last2=Jeffries|first2=Ian|title=The Balkans: a post-communist history|year=2007|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-58328-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=G6iBAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA516&dq=Serbian+historians+Albanian#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Albanian&f=false|page=516|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Janssens50">{{cite book|last=Janssens|first=Jelle|title=State-building in Kosovo. A plural policing perspective|year=2015|publisher=Maklu|isbn=978-90-466-0749-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=YS15BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA50&dq=Serbian+historians+kosovo#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20kosovo&f=false|page=50|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Schwartz45">{{cite book|last=Schwartz|first=Stephen|title=Kosovo: Background to a war|year=2000|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=978-1-898855-56-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jL4tAQAAIAAJ&q=Serb+historiography+great+migration&dq=Serb+historiography+great+migration|page=45|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Janjetovic7">{{cite journal|last=Janjetović|first=Zoran|title=From Foe to Friend and back. Albanians in Serbian History Textbooks 1918–2000|url=http://balkanologie.revues.org/460|journal=Balkanologie|volume=4|issue=1/2|year=2000|ref=harv}} para. 7.</ref><ref name="Malcolm20">{{cite book|last=Malcolm|first=Noel|chapter=Is it true that Albanians in Kosova are not Albanians, but descendants from Albanianized Serbs?|editor1-last=Di Lellio|editor1-first=Anna|title=The case for Kosova: Passage to independence|year=2006|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=978-0-85728-712-0|url=https://books.google.com/?id=aNEW0jtOjK8C&pg=PA20&dq=Serbian+historiography+Arnauta%C5%A1#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Arnauta%C5%A1&f=false|page=20|ref=harv}}</ref> Serbian national history views the Albanian presence in Kosovo apart from being recent immigrants as one that strongly supported and reinforced Ottoman rule meant to dislodge Serbs and to enforce Muslim control.<ref name="Anscombe769770">{{harvnb|Anscombe|2006|pp=769–770.}} "According to Serbian national history, Kosovo's Serbs rose up to join the advancing Habsburgs in the struggle to drive out the Ottomans. When the Habsburg army withdrew, 37,000 Serbian families left with them, or fled ahead of the reconquering Ottoman horde, in answer to an 'invitation' from the Emperor Leopold I to settle in Hungary. Their places in Kosovo were taken by Albanians, deported or encouraged to migrate from northern Albania by the Ottomans to ensure the permanent displacement of the rebellious Serbs. Catholics among the Albanians soon converted to Islam and the settlers became staunch supporters of the Ottoman regime. Thus, Kosovo's Albanians are relatively recent immigrants, settled by the state to displace Serbs and to buttress Muslim rule."</ref>
Many Serbian historians reject that Albanian family clans during the Ottoman period assisted to safeguard and preserve Orthodox monasteries and churches in Kosovo.<ref name="Udovicki29"/> Instead they contend that Albanians held imperial Ottoman military and administrative employment and were to blame as much as the Turks for the turmoil that forced many Serbs in 1690 and 1734 to migrate northward.<ref name="Udovicki29">{{cite book|last=Udovički|first=Jasminka|chapter=The bonds and the fault lines|editor1-last=Udovički|editor1-first=Jasminka|editor2-last=Ridgeway|editor2-first=James|title=Burn this house: The making and unmaking of Yugoslavia|year=2000|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=978-0-8223-2590-1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=GuGe9fy4raoC&pg=PA29&dq=Serb+historians+kosovo#v=onepage&q=Serb%20historians%20kosovo&f=false|page=29|ref=harv}}</ref>
=== Independent Serbia ===
Serbian historiography holds the view that Western powers have always targeted Serbia.<ref name="Gilberg7">{{cite book|last=Gilberg|first=Trond|chapter="Yugoslav" Nationalism at the End of the Twentieth Century|editor1-last=Suryadinata|editor1-first=Leo|title=Nationalism and globalization: East and West|year=2000|publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies|isbn=978-981-230-073-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=F9LxMx9ThRgC&pg=PA7&dq=Serbian+historiography+Pan+Slavism#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historiography%20Pan%20Slavism&f=false|page=7|ref=harv}}</ref>
Differing from a Bosnian nationalist perspective, nationalist Serbian historians have asserted that [[Sandžak]] has 420,000 people of which 60% are Bosniaks and the region encompasses an area of 8,201 km<sup>2</sup>.<ref name="Ruma146">{{cite book|last=Rüma|first=Inan|chapter=Turkish Foreign Policy towards the Balkans: Overestimated change within underestimated continuity?|editor1-last=Oktav|editor1-first=Özden Zeynep|title=Turkey in the 21st century: Quest for a new foreign policy|year=2013|publisher=Ashgate Publishing|isbn=978-1-317-00598-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=pceXCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA146&dq=Serbian+historians+Bosniaks#v=onepage&q=Serbian%20historians%20Bosniaks&f=false|page=146|ref=harv}}</ref>

[[Southwest Jiaotong University|Tangshan College of Engineering]] {{small|(President)}} }} '''Shu-tian Li''' (Shu-tien Li; {{zh|李書田}}) (1900 – 1988) was a citizen of the United States, a [[Chinese American]] educator and [[hydraulic engineer]]. After receiving a Ph.D. degree in engineering/economics from [[Cornell University]] in 1926, Li returned to China to assume a professorship at the [[Peiyang University]].Peiyang University was split into several colleges and universities in [[Beijing]] and [[Tianjin]] after 1950, including the present-time [[Tianjin University]] He became the executive officer of Northern China Hydraulic Commission in 1928.{{cite web|url=http://www.tjsw.gov.cn/pub/tjwcb/shuilibk/shuiwenhua/youjiuls/200911/t20091114_22873.html|title=民间水事|website=Tjsw.gov.cn|accessdate=30 November 2017}} He was a founder of the [[Chinese Hydraulic Engineering Society]] and served as its deputy president and then president for six terms.{{cite web |url=http://www.ches.org.cn/zgslxh/gyxh/lsyg/A060104index_1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707045504/http://www.ches.org.cn/zgslxh/gyxh/lsyg/A060104index_1.htm |archivedate=2011-07-07 |df= }} Later he was appointed to lead the Yellow River Commission.{{lang|zh|《黄河志卷一 黄河大事记》}} At the age of 28, Li was chosen as the president of [[Tangshan College of Engineering]] and became the youngest college administrator in China.{{lang|zh| 西南交通大学档案馆《西南交通大学校名、校址、校长一览表》}} In 1932, he was named the President of the Peiyang Engineering College. He was the longest serving president in Peiyang's first 56 years of history.{{cite web |url=http://www.tju.edu.cn/xxgk/master_old/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101221072331/http://www.tju.edu.cn/xxgk/master_old/ |archivedate=2010-12-21 |df= }} Under his leadership, Peiyang established one of the first graduate engineering programs and the first hydraulic engineering laboratory in China.{{cite web |url=http://www.hydropower.org.cn/info/shownews.asp?newsid=2908 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707050444/http://www.hydropower.org.cn/info/shownews.asp?newsid=2908 |archivedate=2011-07-07 |df= }} Between 1937 and 1949, he led the establishment of several national colleges and universities in western and southwestern China (e.g. {{lang|zh|西北联大, 国立西北工学院, 西康技艺专科学校, 贵阳农工学院, 贵州大学}} and {{lang|zh|北洋西京分院}}). During his leadership at the [[Si-kang Institute of Technology]], the [[Panzhihua Mine]], one of the largest iron (and rare metal) deposits in the world, was discovered. In recognition of his contribution to hydraulic engineering and to China during [[World War II]], Li was awarded a First Order Hydraulic Gold Medal and an Order of Victory of Resistance Against Aggression, respectively, from the Chinese government after the war. He was elected to the National Peking Academy of Sciences{{clarify|date=June 2018}} in 1948. He published many research papers and books on the management and improvement of the nation's water resources, Yellow River basin and northern China harbor.e.g.{{lang|zh|《中国水利问题》, 《永定河治本计划》, 《北方大港之现状及初步计划》}}: Shu-tian Li, managing editor Among these publications, "The Chinese Hydraulic Issues" ({{lang|zh|《中国水利问题》}}), the first comprehensive review and scientific recommendation regarding Chinese water resources, established him as the leading hydraulic engineering authority in China in the 1940s. Li returned to the United States in 1950 to start private engineering practice and academic teaching/research. The Chinese Institute of Engineers (CIE){{cite web|url=http://www.cie-usa.org/|title=Chinese Institute of Engineers ? USA|website=Cie-usa.org|accessdate=30 November 2017}} awarded Li the CIE annual award in 1963 for his work on the Unified Energy-Matrix Analysis.{{cite web|url=http://www.cie-gnyc.org/newsletter/cie_award_2007.pdf|format=PDF|title=Other recipients of the award during the last 50 years included Nobel Prize winners Tsung Tao Li, Chen-Ning Yang, Samuel Ting and Charles Kao; architect I. M. Pei; entrepreneur An Wang; Dr. Li's student at Tangshan College of Engineering Tung-Yen Lin|website=Cie-gnyc.org|accessdate=30 November 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725171151/http://www.cie-gnyc.org/newsletter/cie_award_2007.pdf|archivedate=25 July 2011|df=}} For his contribution to concrete engineering, he received the highest award from the American Concrete Institute in 1985.{{cite web |url=http://www.concrete.org/MEMBERS/mem_info_honorary.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202135638/http://www.concrete.org/MEMBERS/mem_info_honorary.htm |archivedate=2010-12-02 |df= }} He also served on a US congressional advisory board. He was credited with establishing the Phi Tau Phi Scholastic Honor Society of America.{{cite web |url=http://www.phitauphi.org/EastAmerica/PREAMBLE.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727173623/http://www.phitauphi.org/EastAmerica/PREAMBLE.htm |archivedate=2011-07-27 |df= }} He published 17 books and more than 800 research papers during his lifetime. Li died at the age of 88.Examples of notable people whom Li had close association with during his lifetime included Ch'en Li-fu (his classmate at Peiyang and former Secretary of Education in China), [[Y.H. Ku]], [[C. C. Li]] and David K. Cheng. He was an active [[philatelist]] and a devout Southern Baptist during his life. ==Personal life== His brother, Shu-hua Li or [[Li Shu-hua]] ({{lang|zh|李书华}}) was a physicist, and a former Secretary of Education in [[China]],{{dubious|date=June 2018}} and contributed to the founding of [[UNESCO]].C. Martin Wilbur, Preface to ''The Reminiscences of Li Shu-Hua''; as part of Columbia University's Chinese Oral History Project Li was the maternal grandfather of [[Gilbert Chu]], an oncologist and professor of biochemistry at Stanford University, [[Steven Chu]], a [[Nobel Prize]] winner in physics and the USA Secretary of Energy in the [[Barack Obama|Obama]] Administration{{cite web |url=https://www.energy.gov/news/7660.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317135211/http://www.energy.gov/news/7660.htm |archivedate=2011-03-17 |df= }} and [[Morgan Chu]], an intellectual property lawyer. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Li, Shu-tian}} [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American engineers]] [[Category:Chinese emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Chinese expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:Educators from Hebei]] [[Category:Presidents of universities and colleges in China]] [[Category:Yellow River]] [[Category:Cornell University alumni]] [[Category:Hydraulic engineering]] [[Category:Hydraulics]] [[Category:Water resources management]] [[Category:Tianjin University alumni]] [[Category:Concrete pioneers]] [[Category:Tianjin University faculty]] [[Category:Southwest Jiaotong University faculty]] [[Category:Northwestern Polytechnical University faculty]] [[Category:Guizhou University faculty]] [[Category:People from Qinhuangdao]] [[Category:Southern Baptists]] [[Category:Chinese Civil War refugees]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} [[File:Carfaxtower fromcornmarket.jpg|thumb|The [[Carfax, Oxford|Carfax]] Tower, dated from the 13th century, "witnessed" the described events.]]
The '''St Scholastica Day riot''' of 10 February 1355 is one of the more notorious events in the [[history of Oxford]], England.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.oxford.gov.uk/PageRender/decAC/Top_ten_astonishing_facts_occw.htm |title=Top_ten_astonishing_facts |date=15 December 2009 |publisher=[[Oxford City Council]], UK |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091215225140/http://www.oxford.gov.uk/PageRender/decAC/Top_ten_astonishing_facts_occw.htm |archive-date=2009-12-15}}</ref> Sparked off by a tavern dispute between two students and a taverner, the riot lasted two days and resulted in a large number of deaths among local citizens and students. The ensuing pacification led to a reinforcement and enlargement of the privileges and liberties of the academic institutions over the town.
==Background and dispute== [[File:Site of the swindlestock tavern.jpeg|thumb|upright|Site of the Swindlestock Tavern, now a Santander Bank]] The seed of the riot was an altercation in the Swindlestock Tavern in [[Oxford]] (now the site of the Santander Bank on [[Carfax, Oxford|Carfax]], on the corner of [[St Aldate's, Oxford|St Aldate's]] and [[Queen Street, Oxford|Queen Street]]) between two students of the [[University of Oxford]], Walter Spryngeheuse and Roger de Chesterfield, and the taverner, John Croidon. They complained about the quality of drinks, which led to an exchange of rude words that ended with the students throwing their drinks in the taverner's face and assaulting him.<ref name="Miller"/> Retaliation for the incident led to armed clashes between [[Town and gown|locals and students]].
The [[mayor of Oxford]], John de Bereford, asked the [[List of Chancellors of the University of Oxford|Chancellor of the University of Oxford]], [[Humphrey de Cherlton]], to arrest the two students, to no avail. Instead, 200 students supported Spryngeheuse and Chesterfield, allegedly assaulting the mayor and others.<ref name="Miller"/> As the situation escalated, locals from the surrounding countryside poured in, crying: "Havac! Havoc! Smyt fast, give gode knocks!"<ref>{{Cite book |title=Oxford |last=Morris |first=James |publisher=Harcourt |year=1965 |page=69 |author-link=Jan Morris}}</ref>
A riot broke out and lasted two days, which left 63 students and perhaps 30 locals dead.<ref name="Miller"/><ref name="Ward">{{Cite web |url=http://www.wardsbookofdays.com/10february.htm |title=10 February |date=19 August 2010 |website=http://www.wardsbookofdays.com/ |publisher=Ward's Book of Days |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819222053/http://www.wardsbookofdays.com/10february.htm |archive-date=2010-08-19 |access-date=15 February 2016}}</ref> The students were eventually routed.
==Resolution== [[File:Swindlestock tavern plaque.jpeg|thumb|The plaque commemorating the place of the ''Swindlestock Tavern'', from 1250 to 1709]]
The dispute was eventually settled in favour of the University, when a special charter was created. Annually thereafter, on 10 February the saint's day of St [[Scholastica]], the mayor and councillors had to march bareheaded through the streets, attend [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]], and pay to the university a fine of one penny for every scholar killed, a total of 5[[shilling|s]], 3[[Penny (English coin)|d]]. The penance ended 470 years later in 1825, when the mayor refused to take part.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/10/day-1355-university-fracas-ends-93-dead-birth-600-year-long/ |title=On this day in 1355: University fracas ends with 93 dead and the birth of a 600-year-long tradition |last=Selwood |first=Dominic |date=10 February 2017 |work=The Telegraph |access-date=8 February 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170303014653/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/10/day-1355-university-fracas-ends-93-dead-birth-600-year-long/ |archive-date=3 March 2017 |dead-url=no |language=en-GB |issn=0307-1235 |df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Sullivan2012">{{Cite book |url={{google books|id=r9kSDQAAQBAJ|pg=PT54|plainurl=yes}} |title=Bloody British History: Oxford |last=Sullivan |first=Paul |date=31 January 2012 |publisher=History Press |isbn=9780752481975 |page=54 |access-date=9 February 2018}}</ref>
==Aftermath== In an act of conciliation on 10 February 1955, the Mayor was given an honorary degree and the Vice-Chancellor was made an Honorary Freeman, at a commemoration of the events of 1355.<ref name="Miller">{{cite journal | first = Carol M. | last = Miller | url =http://fch.fiu.edu/FCH-1993/Miller_1993.htm | title = The St. Scholastica Day Riot: Oxford after the Black Death | journal = FCH Annals – Journal of the Florida Conference of Historians | pages = 29–42 | volume = 1 | date = June 1993 | accessdate = 6 September 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151207214634/http://fch.fiu.edu/FCH-1993/Miller_1993.htm | archivedate = 7 December 2015| df = dmy-all }} ([http://fch.ju.edu/fch_vol_1.pdf PDF of entire volume] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151014101915/http://fch.ju.edu/fch_vol_1.pdf |date=14 October 2015| format = pdf | deadurl = no }})</ref>
The riot was a culmination of other riots in Oxford, which resulted in over 90 deaths.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.oxfordtimes.co.uk/leisure/history_heritage/history/9200746.print/ |title=Rioting over wine led to 90 deaths |last=Koenig |first=Chris |work=[[The Oxford Times]] |access-date=17 August 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706110215/http://www.oxfordtimes.co.uk/leisure/history_heritage/history/9200746.print/ |archive-date=6 July 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the 1850s novel ''[[The Adventures of Mr. Verdant Green]]'' by [[Cuthbert Bede]], students still saw St Scholastica's Day as an opportunity for a confrontation.
